10 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
13.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 novembre 2020
Information / Review English

TRI: Of Friendship and Madness is a puzzle / adventure game developed by Rat King Entertainment.

Gameplay / Story

As an introduction to the game, the player has to go through a kind of course in which a ghostly figure explains the basic control elements. The character is controlled using the WASD keys, while the camera is moved either with the mouse or the arrow keys. The commands jump, crouch and run are also carried out via the keyboard. Then it goes straight to the level. In these you have to operate switches, find fox statues and place them on appropriate pedestals to complete the level. After a short time, the player has the opportunity to place three points on the floor as well as on walls or objects in order to form a triangle, creating triangular platforms. These can be used to reach higher corridors and make gorges passable. The skill not only helps to complete the level, but also to collect the golden idols that are hidden in the levels.

To do this, triangles have to be cleverly placed in order to overcome abysses and to climb high walls. However, the increasingly complex level structures require brains, creative thinking, a lot of dexterity and spatial imagination. The transcendent game story is about ancient gods, foxes and mysterious forces and is told between the level sections using philosophical phrases - but is only of secondary importance for the actual game. The spiritual atmosphere comes into its own thanks to the color scheme, the washed-out look, which looks as if it were hand-drawn, and the oriental music.

Pro

+ calm and almost meditative atmosphere
+ minimalistic graphics work with clear colors
+ Music to relax
+ thought out puzzles
+ collectable items
+ Achievements and trading cards

Contra

- Puzzles are too easy
- Allure is lost over time

Conclusion

TRI: Of Friendship and Madness offers you an imaginative, mysterious and spiritually inspired world, which is rounded off with easy puzzles.


Information / Review Deutsch

TRI: Of Friendship and Madness ist ein Puzzle/Abenteuer-Spiel, welches von Rat King Entertainment entwickelt wurde.

Gameplay / Geschichte

Als Einführung in das Spiel, muss der Spieler eine Art Parcour durchlaufen, in dem eine geisterhafte Gestalt die grundlegenden Steuerungselemente erklärt. Die Spielfigur wird über die Tasten WASD gesteuert, gleichzeitig wird wahlweise mit der Maus oder den Pfeiltasten die Kamera bewegt. Auch die Befehle Springen, Ducken und Rennen erfolgen über die Tastatur. Anschließend geht es sofort in die Level. In diesen müssen Schalter betätigt, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ gefunden und auf entsprechenden Sockeln abgelegt werden, um das Level abzuschließen. Bereits nach kurzer Zeit erhält der Spieler die Möglichkeit drei Punkte auf den Boden sowie auf Wänden oder Objekten zu platzieren, um ein Dreieck zu formen, wodurch dreieckige Plattformen entstehen. Über diese können höher gelegene Gänge erreicht und Schluchten passierbar gemacht werden. Die Fähigkeit hilft nicht nur dabei, das Level zu beenden, sondern auch, die goldenen Idole zu sammeln, die in den Levelen versteckt sind.

Hierzu müssen Dreiecke geschickt platziert werden, um Abgründe zu überwinden und an hohen Mauern hinaufzukommen. Allerdings fordern die immer komplexer werdenden Levelstrukturen Köpfchen, kreatives Denken, viel Geschicklichkeit und räumliches Vorstellungsvermögen. Die Spielgeschichte handelt von alten Göttern, Füchsen und geheimnisvollen Kräften und wird zwischen den Level-Abschnitten durch philosophische Phrasen erzählt - ist für das eigentliche Spielgeschehen allerdings nur nebensächlich. Die spirituelle Atmosphäre kommt auch durch die Farbgebung, die verwaschene Optik, die wirkt als wären sie handgezeichnet, und die orientalisch anmutende Musik zur Geltung.

Pro

+ ruhige und fast meditative Atmosphäre
+ minimalistische Grafik arbeitet mit klaren Farben
+ Musik zum entspannen
+ durchdachte Rätsel
+ sammelbare Gegenstände
+ Errungenschaften und Trading Cards

Kontra

- Rätsel sind zu leicht
- Reiz geht mit der Zeit veloren

Fazit

TRI: Of Friendship and Madness bietet dir eine fantasievolle, mysteriöse und spirituell angehauchte Welt, welche mit leichten Rätseln abgerundet wird.
 
Knuffybaer[GER]
0
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
19.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 mars 2016
Tri is an underated puzzle game with a fantastically unique premise but sadly deserves a lot more attention than it is currently getting.

The games main puzzle concept relies on the use of these triangles you make called tri's. Initially these triangles have restricted use and can only be used to climb up walls. As you progress you unlock new uses for tri's. These include climbing up the sides of walls and reflecting light beams. These tri's are used to tackle every puzzle in the game.

Each level is set in a large freely explorable area. Your goal is to find three red lion statues in order to order the portal to progress to the next level. Completing various puzzles around the level will help you find your way towards these statues. Each puzzle is unique in it's own way, some involving uses of other things such as boxes, buttons or light. Each has it's own unique challenge that can prove quite diffcult.

What's even better about tri though is the way in which they create puzzles means they don't all have a single explicitly chosen solution. You can tackle many puzzles in your own unique way. Some puzzles will have only one solution possible but I found the majority to have multiple ways of doing. This personally adds highly to the user experience by not being restricted unnecessarily.

Puzzle progression in tri works almost perfectly. I could feel the difficulty rising as I progressed through levels but it was never too quick that I couldn't keep up. Earlier levels in the game I could finish in less than 15 minutes but later levels ended up taking me in excess of 1 hour to complete.

Now the reason I say the puzzle progression isn't perfect is because I believe they use the wrong premise to make the last 2 chapters the most difficult. These levels rely heavily on the reflecting light mechanic. The problem is that places tri's in the correct way to reflect light into the area you want it to is notoriously difficult. It's to the point that I almost gave up on the last 2 chapters. But I perseveared and the last chapter ended up taking me over 2 hours to complete because of this. I think the developers made the wrong choose to focus on this mechanic and it will leave a lot of people giving up out of anger.

Achievement hunters will love tri too. Each level has these extra secret findables called idols. To find these is entirely optional but they unlock you bonus content at the main menu. Sometimes they are hidden in obvious places such as behind some stairs or in a small whole in the wall. But more often then not they require some create puzzling to get to. Through my playthrough I didn't manage to find many of these idols and I tried to look for them in every nook and cranny I saw. So I believe these are very difficult to find and would be great to keep people occupied throughout the game.

Tri has a good amount of content contained in it. There are 15 chapters in this game. Overall it took me almost 20 hours to finish the game. This is a good amount of time and content. I believe you could finish it quicker if you were better at puzzles than me though! If you were looking to collect each idol as well I believe this could easily add in excess of 10 hours of playtime to the game.

In terms of graphic style it is very unique and stylish. Tri is one of the most colourful games I have seen in a while. They really do focus on making sure each area is as colourful and unique as possible which I applaude to. The screenshots of the game is personally what caught my attention to buy it. Along with this great graphics style is an excellent soundtrack. It is full of calming music to accompany you through your journey and captures the spirit of the game perfectly.

The story in the game is forgettable at best. Tri's story is told through after level cutscenes and the occasional speaking in game. I couldn't remember any of the story for the life of me which isn't good for a game. It doesn't help either that the vocals are terribly voice acted in a voice that I suppose the person thought would be interesting and unique but is in fact incredibly annoying. Luckily though the gameplay makes up for the boring story.

Overall tri is a puzzle game that really does deserve a lot more attention than it is currently getting. It is almost on par with other great puzzle games such as talos principle and portal. The issues I have with this game are mostly negligable. The issue with the last 2 chapters however did put my overall rating down slightly cause it annoyed me a great deal. But for a price of £12.99 it is quite reasonable for the amount of great content you'll be getting.

TheIronicGamers rating system
  • Don't ever buy this game.
  • Not recommended
  • Maybe consider it on a sale.
  • An average game.
  • Recommended
  • Highly recommended
  • A must play!

For more recommendations and reviews on our favourite up and coming quality games follow Lot's O Giveaway's group curations here!
 
TheIronicGamer

Évaluation publiée le 10 octobre 2014
Charming and uniquely stylish first-person puzzler with fantastic soundtrack. Blends the challenge of puzzle solving with the Zen of exploration and treasure hunting, with a core gameplay that is playful, creative and provides an unusual amount of freedom to the player. Navigating the world of TRI is almost an artistic process in its own right. A must play for any fan of games like Portal, Q.U.B.E, Qbeh, Magrunner, FRACT or puzzle gaming in general.

Tri is a game I really liked. I don't have much to add.

The game is beautiful and the whimsical atmosphere is really captivating. The puzzles are for the most part really rewarding. I had a lot of fun playing this game.

There is 2 thing I didn't see that much and they can be really annoying.
1) If you have a fear of heights, this game WILL trigger your phobia. I had to stop and replay again numerous time just to calm down (But I have an acute phobia though x3)
2) Some puzzles are really, really, REALLY annoying to solve once you figure them out. Especially some light puzzles.

Apart from that, the game is really wonderful.

17.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 octobre 2016
Tri is a game about triangles, and using them to manipulate the world around you with a japanese theme.
Each level has three keys you need to find to finish the level. There are 16 levels.

Pros:
Fantastic music
Quite relaxed and casual
Propper options
Nice controlls and feel
Beautiful graphics and colours

♥♥♥♥:
Some puzzles are unfair.
Some solutions are unfair.
Several ways to instantly die, which seems out of place.
Infrequent autosaving.
If you die, you must load a save. (This is only a ♥♥♥ if you're bad at manually saving constantly)

I finished it, and all in all it was fun, I did however experience many difficult puzzles with very unobvious awnsers to me. I had to stop midgame many times to look up a walkthrough just to progress.
-Basically, this game's solutions are a bit more cryptic than usual and take a lot of tinkering to understand, but if you're willing to spend hours searching in huge worlds (That are stunningly beautiful btw) for secrets and keys, I'd say go for it!

The first levels went smoothly, but after that, levels took 1 hour or more to complete.
-Note: Each level took a long time to complete because there are many puzzles pr. level, and the levels have their own world to explore pretty much.

I feel that I definitively got my money's worth from this game, and if Japanese culture is interesting to you, this is actually really cool. このゲームがとても楽しいと美しいです。
 
RonaldASL
0
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
35.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 février 2017
Tri is a joy to play despite an array of rough spots.

Pros
gameplay − The gleeful embrace of architecture and gravity as the primary game mechanics is thoroughly successful. Approaching the same rooms from different orientations is fun and exciting every time, and statue-collecting is consistently satisfying.
art direction − The geometry, the material palette, and the liberal use of fog-effects all evoke Japanese watercolors without resorting to texture mapping. Nailed it.
soundtrack − The music is fitting and addictive. It's hard not to wish that the score included a few more tracks for additional variety and also just because it's so good.

♥♥♥♥
objective confusion − The mandatory objective of each level is clear (deliver the three red statues to the exit gate), but the secondary objectives are muddled. Each level ends with meaningless statistics of completion time, tris created, and tris deleted—none of which affect completion or achievements. Meanwhile, it's not readily apparent that collecting gold statues is an all-or-nothing matter (i.e. getting 11 statues out of 12 is no better than getting none at all). This is significant because collecting the optional gold statues is as essential to the overall experience as collecting the required red statues.
voice acting − The narrator/guide seems like he should be Japanese if anything, but he instead sounds like a young programmer trying to sound like an old wizard in a game of Dungeons & Dragons.
hidden teleportation − Teleportation points marked with floating sparkles are used throughout the game, typically to avoid tedious or impossible return routes from statue-collection points. Frustratingly, a few times late in the game invisible teleportation happens. A trick that is cool and fun in other games (hooray for Antichamber) is out-of-place in this game, which is all about about approaching architecture from multiple angles. (The level "Red Means Dangerous" is unacceptably cheat-y from this perspective.)
mushy controls − Movement is less than crisp, and if you're used to AAA games, sticking platform jumps consistently may require a bit of adjustment.
surprise death − There's no fall-damage, and jumping into an abyss simply returns the player to the last stable foothold, so there's no reason to save…until the first acid-pit is encountered several levels into the game, at which point it's goodbye progress, hello frustration! Advice: bind quick-save to a favorite key and use it often.
 
jameslucas
274 produits enregistrés

Évaluation publiée le 23 novembre 2016
Эта игра свела меня с моей девушкой с ума настолько, что разработчики затвиттили наши скриншоты.
Если кратко:
1. Эти золотые статуэтки... Настоящий челлендж для любителей пространственных головоломок.
2. Ощущение свободы при решении головоломок.
3. Безумные локации.
4. Здесь даже не сразу замечаешь баги, потому что думаешь, что так было задумано (хвала прозрачным стенам, что только усложнило игру)!
5. Самый длинный финал (длиннее, чем у Кодзимы). Будь мужественен! Дойди до конца.
6. Безбашенные ачивки.
7. Увлекательный геймплей с философским сюжетом.

P.S. Мы сломали шаблон и залезли на деревянные стены (хвала треугольникам!).

Évaluation publiée le 15 aout 2017
Kendi yolunuzu çizdiğiniz-yarattığınız güzel bir Bulmaca-Keşif oyunu TRI: Of Friendship and Madness.

Oyunun başlarında güzel gelen rahatlatıcı bir müzik eşliğinde, bulunduğunuz bölümü geçebilmek için 3 adet heykelciğe ulaşmak amacınız. Heykelciklere giden yolda çizdiğiniz üçgenler en iyi arkadaşınız olacak ki oyun sonuna kadar bu üçgenler sizi varış noktanıza götürecek.

Orta düzeyde başlayıp gittikçe zorlaşan seviye anlayışı, bölüm tasarımları ve oynanış mekanikleri ile kesinlikle tavsiye edeceğim "Bulmaca" oyunları arasında olduğunu rahatlıkla söyleyebilirim. Ama oyunda geçirdiğiniz 2 küsür saatten sonra arkada çalan müzik size bıkkınlık verip zıvanadan çıkarttığı zaman kapatın oyun müziklerini ve internetten aynı ritimde başka bir şeylere bakın size tavsiyem..

8 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
13.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 octobre 2014
I LOVE this game. First of all, it's about foxes, and I love foxes more than anything in the universe. Second of all, the game is a lot of fun, it's well designed, the art style suits it, the music is great, and the puzzles are very well designed.

What you do in this game is you use triangles to traverse areas and solve puzzles. As the game progresses you get a few additional powers for the triangles which are used for later puzzles. The puzzles slowly get more and more complex and challenging and are a lot of fun.

The game has a somewhat Portal feel (at least to me) in how you go about solving puzzles; especially later on in the game once you have all the powers and the puzzles require more thinking. As well, the puzzles don't always obey they laws you expect them to obey, but you learn how they work fairly quickly (although most of them obey the same laws).

It's a fairly relaxed game in that you can't really die (but you sort of can). If you fall into the void you're just reset (and you will fall into it quite a bit), but if you touch a red light beam or fall in acid you die and have to reload a save. Those hazards aren't introduced until later though. Either way, it's easy enough to not fall in, and if you come across a point where you see these hazards just save the game as you can save anywhere (the game does autosave as well at various check points just so you don't have to restart the whole level in the event of forgetting to save and dying).

You have to find three fox statues (called key statues) throughout each level and then bring them back to a certain area where you put them on pillars and they activate a portal to the next level. There are various golden fox statues (called idols) hidden throughout the levels as well. You don't need to collect these but they unlock bonus content (the bonus content seems to just be development notes and level commentaries; you also get achievements for collecting certain ones). Some of them are hidden in fairly obvious places whereas others are hidden in extremely well hidden places (such as places where you would think you're not supposed to go). Some are even hidden in plain sight but getting to them is very difficult.



I'm not sure what else to say about this game, but you should definitely buy it if you like puzzle games.
And it works on Windows, Mac, and Linux; which is really nice as I prefer to play games only on Linux. :p
 
Zukaro Travon
3
7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 avril 2018
So I found this game a few weeks ago during a sale after seeing it on the Featured storepage. I've been on a big kick for 3D platformers, saw this and thought it'd be a fun game to play in between other stuff with longer campaigns.

Now, I want to like this game.

I REALLY want to like this game.

I can't though. I've been trying for 2 hours and this is just impossible. The motion sickness I'm experiencing while playing is killing me. I need to go lay down before I throw up.

Want a more in-depth review?

Pros:
- It has an interesting gameplay mechanic by using geometry to solve puzzles. Guess I owe all of my math teachers an apology
- From what I gathered of the story, it would've been really easy for me to be invested (had the ♥♥♥♥ not outweighed the pros)
- The graphics are pretty and don't require a NASA-grade Space Computer to run the game

♥♥♥♥:
- The narrator. Not only is his accent kinda goofy, which takes me out of the experience, but his execution of monologuing is something to be desired. He goes from using layman's speak to Big Brain Words™. It's ecclectic to say the least. I feel like this was the intent of the developers but it just sorta falls flat. I'm aware you can disable the voice acting through the menu but in my opinion, that's more of a bandaid solution to a wounding problem. If you're planning on sticking with the same voice actor for any future games and don't pass on the criticisms to him (and whoever wrote his script since I'm going to assume they're two different people) then you'll just run into the same problem. It's nice that you can toggle the voice acting on and off, which is something I really would've appreciated having in Dust: An Elysian Tail, but it's not the best solution in my book.
- Oh my god the motion sickness. I didn't even know I HAD motion sickness until I played this game. My eyes are bleeding. My stomach is in my sphincter. For god's sake, send help. I thought this game had motion blur and that might've been the issue but apparently not. Not sure if that makes me more impressed or angry with how much that impacted me. It's really weird though the more I think about it because I've played things like Portal which has you trying to find your orientation in mid-air at high speeds but that didn't make me sick yet this does? I guess that's why it took me by surprise so much.
- The very sudden escalation of difficulty that slammed out of nowhere. Best comparison is if you were taken on a skiing trip, put on the bunny slope, and then right after you somewhat had the Pizza/French Fry technique down, the instructor took you all the way to the top of the mountain on a Double Black Diamond slope and told you that you had to find your own way down.
You're going to hurt yourself.
It will not be fun.
This was not fun.
Honestly, I could've overlooked the sudden spike in difficulty had it not been for the massive motion sickness. It's one thing to be in a difficult puzzle. It is a completely DIFFERENT thing to be in a difficult puzzle, trying not to puke, and then reaugment yourself because for whatever reason, the room got flipped even though you weren't on a wall triangle.
- How poorly explained certain elements of gameplay are. How was I supposed to know there are some triangles you had to delete in a certain order? Unless I missed a line from FoxMonk™ while I was trying not to barf, I don't remember ANY mention of that. Or how is that in those weird wooden panel rooms, I can't draw triangles on the wooden panels BUT IF I DRAW IT FROM THE TILE TO THE WOODEN PANEL, THAT'S SOMEHOW OKAY? I don't get it. If the magic is being surpressed by the wood, the following logic is that you can't let a triangle touch any part of wood.
That's some bs right there I tell ya what.
- The music. What is it? This may seem nitpicky but the environment vs. the choice of instruments just doesn't match up. The world says Asian but the music says... Australian? I can't really put into words well enough what exactly doesn't line up for me. Maybe it's just me but it does take me out of the mood a bit.

I feel bad because I've only barely made it through 1/3 of the game (I quit on level 6) and I couldn't get through it. It doesn't feel fair to judge the game based on that much of the content but I'm physically limited from progressing further. Even just thinking about the game is making me feel sick so this is all that I can base my opinion on.

2/10, Jesus Christ, I'd never make it as an astronaut
 
Un développeur ou une développeuse a répondu à cette évaluation

Évaluation publiée le 6 janvier 2017
After some thought, I've decided to give this game the benefit of the doubt. There's something in this game that's on par with Portal, namely, the core concept of triangle creation. In this game, I learned to Think With Triangles.

The only thing this game needs as of now: more attention! It may not be a perfect game, but it is a gem. The art style is interesting — very reminiscent of Latin American art. The music is cool too! I was surprised at how many of those lesser known and exotic instruments I could name in the soundtrack.

Buy it (I say the full price is worth it, but do it on sale if you really must :P)! Support the devs!

495.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 décembre 2016
TRI, oh man TRI. I love this game so much. It's a 3D puzzle platformer and I honestly think it's one of the best out there. The design is very smart: the puzzles make you feel clever for solving them. Too many puzzle games give me this feeling of "oh man I'm an idiot, why didn't I think of that sooner" but I don't think I ever got that in TRI. The soundtrack is delightfully weird. The style of it is pretty cool and is super cohesive all the way through. It's one of those games that I will wave a flag for until the day I die: I genuinely believe it is one of the best puzzle games out there and that everyone should play it. It's awesome.

Recommandé
9.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 juin 2015
FPS 方式のパズル。私はこの手のタイプのゲームが好きなので比較的楽しめた。

解法が分かるまで何度もエリアを行き来する事になるので、それが面倒と思えてしまう人もいるかも知れない。

パズルは全体的に良くできていると思うが、スマートでないパズルが散見されるのが気になった。泥臭い方法がおそらく正しいと思われるので、解法が分かっても操作がまどろっこしい時があるのが残念。

音楽はオリエンタルな雰囲気でなかなか良い。

難易度は結構高め。シークレットを自力で全て探すのは至難の業だと思う。スピードランなども用意されていて、やり込み要素あり。
 
Spooky
323 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
22.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 février 2021
一款玩法独特的空间解谜游戏，把“画三角”这一基本操作的潜力发挥得淋漓尽致，搭建行走路径、反射光线、建立阻挡墙，画好三角形就可以玩转这复杂而奇妙的空间。解谜部分设计精妙，水平直追另一款空间解谜神作Antichamber，部分收集品的位置极其隐蔽，全收集几乎要去到所有能到的地方，探索感一级棒。音乐美术有强烈的异域民俗风情，剧情暖心，手感和物理效果舒适。唯一需要注意的是，由于空间复杂、没有地图和频繁的重力反转，游戏对空间感较差和严重3D眩晕的玩家可能不太友好。

总评：9/10，令人耳目一新的冷门佳作。
 
MIA

Bonus points for fox theme.

Évaluation publiée le 2 octobre 2016
Puzzle Game in prima persona ben riuscito, pieno di atmosfera e caratterizzato da un level design veramente di alto livello.
Gameplay solidissimo, pochi elementi fondamentali a nostra disposizione ma le possibilià di superare i vari ostacoli sono veramente illimitate. Non è particolarmente ostico (lo diventa magari se si vuole scovare tutti i collezionabili), è necessaria comunque una buona osservazione degli scenari e un pensiero particolarmente elastico.
Decisamente consigliato agli amanti del genere.

Would get migraine again, 11/10.
Go and give it a TRI!
 
noMercy
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
35.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 juillet 2015
TRI
is a 1st person puzzle platformer from Ratking Entertainment, a small 2-person ( both young, very humble and sympathetic in their online presence, a true indie) dev studio in germany.
The game started off as a game jam entry and garnered so much positive feedback that the two decided to flesh it out.
After many iterations (you can find more on the development on their YT channel or Blog [ratking.de]) a truly beautiful and surreal game with mind (and physics-) bending mechanics and a nice narration as the cherry on top of it all emerged.

Story
You as the player are dropped into the world of the "odd gods" and shortly after meet a monk who will be your spirit guide and is in some kind of adversarial relation with a fox that pops up here and there, mostly making you life harder rather than helping you out.
(Once he even turns gravity on it's head to confuse you!)
That monk tells you that - in the beginning - there were 3 foxes. So what happened along the way?
While I'm happy that the story is there and it feels like it really is an organic part of the game, what motivated me to play TRI is nonetheless the gameplay.

Gameplay
The main strength of the game are the mechanics and the (in part) anarchic puzzles.
Your main tool to traverse the world and find the three fox statues that enable you to leave the level and progress to the next one is triangles.
You can build structures with them, like bridges and so on. But you can also walk on walls... and roofs.
And you can use them to redirect light (which I am atrociously bad at btw...) or little Kami spirits.
The puzzles are super hard and make you think out of the box very often.
Also, there are a certain amount of optional collectibles in every level and let me tell you: In order to find all of these, you really have to have some masochistic character traits!
(I'm trying to collect them all...)

I play this game whenever I feel like challenging myself and then it's rewarding as hell. It's not something for turning off your thinking apparatus and just killing time, though...

I am currently in Chapter 13 from 16 and will edit this review if any of my impressions change but at this point I want to strongly recommend this game!
 
Asslord
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
24.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 novembre 2014
I just finished the game, and this will not contain any spoiler.
I discovered this game in the Portal 2 steam news thing. I watched the trailer. I loved it. The idea is pure genius. I played the demo later. I loved that too. I then waited patiently for the game to release, all the while playing the demo a lot. Then it was released. I was ecstatic. Now, enough about me, the game!
The game starts with an easy tutorial level, in which you are introduced to your "mentor", the Monk, and to the game's objective: finding his friend the Fox [if I remember correctly, in the alpha period of the game, the fox was evil and you had to look him the strange world]. You will also see "visions" of the Fox throughout the levels. You then go to the Odd God's world: a world mostly comprised of giant cubes filled with puzzles floating in the middle of emptiness. No wonder the Gods are called Odd! In the second level, you are introduced to this game's collectibles: the Idols of Unnessecary Knowldege. Just my type of thing ! The Idols unlock artwork, in-game commentary and info on the game while it was in developpment. Each level has a few Idols, and one super secret one. They are quite hard to find sometimes, and not mandatory to beating the game. The TRI is encountered in the third level, if I am not mistaken. It works really well. If the TRIs are yellow, you can walk on them, if red, you cannot. You also cannot place TRIs on wood [which has the beautiful meaning that TRIs can only be put on an eternal materials. Well, to me]. Later in the game you encounter the GraviTRI [not the official name], which gives each TRI it's own gravity: if you have a slanted TRI, your gravity will become slanted too when you walk on it. So you could make a chain of TRIs that lead to the ceiling and walk on the ceiling! I read some people had motion sickness, but I [thank the Odd Gods] did not. The games contains 16 levels, which seems short, but isn't. To finish a level, you must gather the 3 Fox Status and place them on an altar. The levels are beautiful, stunning and extremelly well-crafted and brain-melting at times. The music is just perfect. The game seems to be reparted in a few "sections", with each section having 3 music segments that loop. The music is so good that the looping is not a problem to me. The story is nice, simple and touching: a tale of friendship, madness, and Foxes. The game is fairly glitchless: the 2 glitches I encountered were fixed, and the last level had a slightly game-breaking glitch, but thankully Ratking told us how to fix it in the "stuck thread". The developper commentary is also a bit flawed: the music doesn't get less loud, unlike when you talk with the Monk: so you'll hear the the great music and the devs talking about things at the same volume, which makes it hard to understand it at times.
Overall, this is a great game. I loved it. I strongly recommend this to any amateur of FPS puzzle- and exploration-games. And you can buy the soundtrack! What's not to like?
Thank you, Ratking entertainment, for making such a unique and exceptionnal game. I love you!
Edit:
The way death is handled is questionnable: if you fall in bottomless hole/void, you immediatly respawn at a predetermined point, which is nice. But if you touch a red lazer or acid, you die and have to choose a previous save. So make sure you save often.
Oh, and the TRIs are the magical triangle-platforms. When you create one, the world becomes grey, except for a coloured zone which indicates where you can place the next point. Maybe I should've mentionned that earlier...
 
happyW12

Good puzzle, but the movement is clumsy.

I like the design - challenging and creative. I am on the 4th world, it's fairly big and the player needs to draw triangles to reach different platforms. The game is bug free, however the movement is accelerated, making it difficult to control, as a result I can hardly jump up stairs without falling. I tried to make the movement more "steady" with CE, but it didn't go as well as I planned, will need more practice.

19.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 décembre 2017
Review is complete*

This is a semi-incomplete review as I've only recently started the game, but I've been impressed enough to comment on it so far.

A puzzle game? A find-it adventure? An extradimentional platformer? A fox-hunting extraviganza with seemingly no fox? I forgot, but I'm starting to get drugged looking at it.

This game is quite trippy, once I realized it started doing some... bizarre things... perspective tricks? Impossible rooms? Maybe the fox knows more about it? Ask him.


Who knew that a game about making disjointed polygon errors could be so intreaguing? And perhaps it's because it's consistent with the Japanese folklore of the bizarre world of the gods? Of course we are talking foxes here. There is nothing straightforward about them, and if you like their tricks?

They have plenty for you.


As far as my criticism on the game, I'd say the devs hit a home run on the art style. This game is ideal for a toaster regardless that it's 3D, but the color pallet really sell this extradimentional realm. (I sadly hate red to yellow color pallets, does Blue Fox have a blue temple I can go to sometime?)

Otherwise, the music is nice, but the eastern chant mock-ups get a bit old. Perhaps intentional because... madness? Again ask the fox, I don't know.



-------
Whatever else I figure out about this weird yet intreaguing gem of a game in the meantime will be down here in a log.

Update: I've now completed the game, and yes I can indeed say that this game is the trippiest thing I have ever played. It lacks a shiny coat of paint, but it's writing kept me laughing, gameplay kept me engaged, and surprises left me baffled.

I can say the music criticism remains. I like the blend of ... oddly Jamacan sounding chant with acoustic guitar. But of course, it will get boring to listen to after some time.

I kinda wish it would have had a dynamic tracking, such as a new track or instrument that plays when you do things right? Maybe when you pick up one of the red statues? Either way, it wasn't too bad.

There is no level editor, but the story is what is there. A level editor wouldn't really make the game last much longer. You'll probably take over 20 hours to complete the main part of the game if you take some time with figuring out puzzles? They can be quite time consuming. The ending was quite worth it, and the title screen credits song is awesome.

This game was quite an indie gem for a puzzler, and it's sad that it's semi-gloss polish is probably what keeps it from being more popular. The use of Japanese fox folklore sells this world though. Even though the voice felt budget, the writing made the monk believable. The fox's actions made him likeable. And I'd totally buy another game with this theme and writing that went into it. The further and further I played, I really felt as if the fox was watching and actively playing tricks on me with his oddball world.

Perhaps you should play a trick on him to save him from his madness?
 
jrubz
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2
Recommandé
5.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 avril 2023
爬塔爬累了来写写。

刚开始非常难玩，走路不顺滑、视角转换不方便（可能因为我用触控板）、跳跃很困难（长按空格和不长按有什么区别？反馈完全一样，但长按+方向键莫名其妙能跳上更高的台阶，让我疑惑，降低体验感），还很容易方向键按太猛跳过了掉下来。也许制作组也意识到这一点，允许玩家随时随地快速存档、读挡。

拿到第一个技能的时候体验一下子好起来了，创造自己道路的感觉实在是很棒，消除”前人”留下三角的体验也很奇妙。第三个迷宫看到倒挂的树，还想着这游戏里的迷宫是不是可以上下颠倒，发觉不行之后有点失望。后来才发现这里的“颠倒”和下一个能力是呼应的，甚至说，我觉得比起颠倒迷宫，第二个能力更棒（因为能去到的地方和通路更多）。第一次尝试第二种能力的时候，我终于理解了这个游戏为什么要做成第一人称视角（虽然导致我跳得很痛苦）。回想起来，一般解谜游戏获得新道具/能力之后，这个道具/能力基本只能在特定障碍出发挥作用，让玩家可以去到更多地方，此外可能就没什么作用了。但是这个游戏，每获得一次新能力，都可以让我感叹“哇！还可以这样”，自由度大大上升，趣味性指数级增长！

除了技能之外，迷宫和指引也很棒。制作人很擅长利用空间，特别是在我看来一般比较容易被忽视的“高度”，所以能给我一种迷宫很大、可供探索区域很多的感觉（其实可能并不大）。可惜目前玩到的迷宫（1-6）没什么特色，虽然会有灯笼或瓷器之类的要素，但墙面和空间的整体感觉很相似，如果不同的迷宫能够更有各自的记忆点就好了。此外，引导很棒，虽然知道要画三角，但具体有什么画法还是要慢慢学习的。制作组会给玩家提示，但又不是很生硬的教学，比如说，第5关的时候，第一次出现要爬很高一段距离的情况，一上来我也不知道要怎么爬，但是现成的几个三角“告诉”了我可以这样做。还比如说，获得第二个技能之后，面前正好有一串中间缺了一个的三角，补上那个三角的时候，自然就知道以后要怎么做了。尊重玩家的智商，并且没有植入出戏的教程解说，很好。

还有还有，收集奖励是制作花絮、评论音轨等等，让我很有动力找小神像。

感觉很棒的瞬间
- 新画三角的一个顶点叠在之前画的三角上
- 仰头的时候发现正好有个狐狸面具“盯“着我
- 搬开堵住门的一堆箱子
- 消除三角时候的“嘘嘘”声（提醒你先消除另一块）
- 一闪而过的狐狸
- 在犄角旮旯找到小神像
- 在高层俯瞰刚进来时候的路
- 第一次顺着三角形爬上墙壁
 
forsomereason

28.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 janvier 2020
I really liked the first few levels, there were large open areas, nice geometry and styling to look at and some puzzles that were interesting to solve. I even went as far as to collect all the idols since it seemed a lot of fun to platform my way to hidden areas and find all the secrets in a level.

Unfortunately, the second half of the game made me realize that I wasn't enjoying the game anymore, I just wanted to finish it and see what would happen to the foxes. Almost all problems can be solved by brute-forcing hundreds of triangles, almost no thinking necessary.

Other reviewers have perfectly outlined what the issues are with the game considering the puzzles, environments and mechanics, so I'd rather not repeat what has already been said.

I really wanted to like it, but I'm afraid I'm not recommending it to future players.

31.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 mai 2016
If you're patient and can handle a few weak points, this game is probably for you.

Maybe it's just because I haven't played many games like these, but I was consistently astounded by how creative and diverse the puzzles were. Even with new abilities that seemed to break the game, the developers somehow managed to craft some really, really clever challenges here and there. I found myself consistently questioning which way was up as I went out of my way to find all the hidden idols - some of which were really devious. Little buggers.

I guess the only things I really disliked were the voice of the monk (More of a personal thing) and the controls occasionally. Being unable to hold space to climb onto a box or just falling off one of your triangles - they tend to happen a lot. Otherwise, I had a blast solving all those puzzles.

Love the fox, by the way. He's adorable. Except in level 15. He was a little frigger in that one.

Non recommandé
17.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 novembre 2018
I finally finished the game and I don't recommend it.
It started well but become problematic the more I dove into the levels.

The atmosphere and artistic direction of the game is great, the story can be forgotten however. The music is funny and pleasant, I often sang along it while solving puzzles. :)

For the rest however, it's painful. One of the main issues are the controls which are often slow and sometimes unresponsive. Missing a jump happens quite often which is problematic for a platforming game. Head bobbing is annoying as well, especially when the game drop frames (I have a very good computer, it shouldn't be happening).

However my main issue are the Triangle behaviors (SPOILER AHEAD) : at one point you can start walking on walls thanks to the Triangles you draw on surfaces. In some cases you can end-up upside down and if you look back you suddenly fall because the game collisions/detection of the surface change. This is very annoying because it's unpredictable.

My second issue is how often puzzle solutions are based on hidden information. Things you can't guess and should be taught by the game. Also the game breaks its own rules all the time to implement new game mechanics making things very confusing. I often ended-up stuck in one part of a level because suddenly a red laser which kills you doesn’t anymore for some reason in another room. Inconsistency in the game design make the experience frustrating and puzzle solving un-fun.

Bonus : Walls that can be taken apart block by block that look like any other walls. You can only discover them if you are close enough and your cursor appearance change. I would be okay if it was only for hidden treasures and trophies, but that's not the case.

打折后入手。原本以为很大的游戏发现才两百兆，但麻雀虽小五脏俱全

TRI 是一款非常好的益智游戏，为了寻找黄金小狐狸费劲心思。甚至你可以通过搭建的三角形跑到地图外面，让我觉得这游戏的可玩性大大加强，游戏不大但可以看出作者很细心在做，一些隐藏着的狐狸雕塑甚至在你眼皮底下你仍旧不知道，这也是游戏的一大乐趣吧。

Recommandé
27.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 juillet 2021
Портал с треугольниками и лисичками. И без порталов)

Геймплей заключается в том, чтобы на протяжении 15 уровней пробираться к выходу с локации, предварительно открыв телепорт, установив 3 статуи лисиц. В общем-то их поиск и есть основная задача. Сложность уровней постепенно возрастает, добавляются новые механики (отражение лучей света и возможность ходить в любой проекции, если дорога связана), уменьшается количество мест для создания треугольников (больше деревянный покрытий, на которых нельзя строить), добавляются угрозы за уровни (лазеры и химикаты). ближе к концу телепорты, уровни более обширны и не сразу понятно куда идти и что делать. Невероятно простая механика по строительству треугольников превращена в отличную головоломку с интересными уровнями и практически безграничным простором для создания маршрутов. Для любителей собрать коллекционки по уровням разложены золотые идолы, для сбора которых придется обыскать каждый угол локаций, в награду же открываются доп. материалы о создании уровней, комментарии разработчиков и т.д.

Музыка - Бренчания шамана при медитации, тянет в сон, но в то же время неплохо подходит игре с ее вымышленным миром.

Графика - Простая, но очень приятная, красивые локации прилагаются.

Сюжет - Для галочки - помогаем спасти друга-лиса монаха (который и сам не монах, а второй лис-бог), находящегося в другом измерении.

Любителям головоломок однозначно рекомендую. Проходить уровни и искать секреты невероятно интересно и затягивающе.

7 золотых пупсиков из 10
 
BuBuZyB
3,206 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
25.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 décembre 2014
PROS:
*Great visuals
*Impressive levels and design
*Unique and interesting triangle mechanics
*Good atmosphere
*Music fits
*Save and quicksave features
*Some replayability if the player is interested in collectibles or competition

♥♥♥♥:
*Not much emphasis on actual puzzles; platforming and exploration are the stars here
*Some frustrating elements, like directing balls of light with curving paths to particular destinations or placing the three points of a triangle at precisely the right positions
*Minimal story
*Little to no sense of connection between levels
*Some collectibles locations are too hard to find without a guide

GAME LENGTH:
Even with a guide to the collectible locations, achievement hunters can expect to take 20+ hours to complete the game without a walkthrough. Those interested only in completing the game can expect to finish in substantially less time, perhaps around 12 hours.

SCORE:
7 out of 10

My feelings about this game are in conflict, partly due to my expectation that it would have a heavier focus on actual puzzles and meaningful exploration.

I spent the first 10 or so of TRI's 16 levels wondering where the puzzles were. I figured that the platforming (enabled by the game's TRI mechanic, which allows the player to walk on walls and ceilings) would largely be an interesting means of navigating from puzzle A to puzzle B, which I would then solve to get the statuettes that are needed to proceed to the next stage. Instead, the platforming itself often seemed to be the puzzle. Reaching my goals was mostly about locating and climbing to them, not thinking about what actions I needed to take and in what order. Even reaching areas that appeared inaccessible from the start was just a matter of moving through the level and, say, falling down the right hole. The last third of the game began to incorporate some puzzles, but they were too little (too few, too simple), too late.

I could have accepted this problem as a feature rather than a failure. Perhaps the developers intended for the TRI mechanics to be the stars of the game instead of the puzzles. Unfortunately, I found myself fighting with some of the TRI mechanics as well, particularly the light reflection. There are "puzzles" that involve reflecting a beam of light off the player's placed triangles to hit a crystal, which powers some part of the environment. For me, setting the three points of my triangles just so was very time-consuming and not fun at all, especially when the beam of light had to be reflected down hallways or holes in the ground to reach other rooms. Sometimes the reflected light was dangerous, so I had to duck under or platform around it to get a good enough vantage point to precisely draw my next triangle. Worse than the light beams, however, were the "kami", balls of light that follow a set, curving path from some spawner and bounce off your triangles. The curve in their path is largely preserved after they bounce, so placing triangles to get the kami where I wanted them to go was even more difficult. Fortunately, the most frustrating of these scenarios are intended to be completed only if the player wants to collect the optional golden idols.

As a completionist and fan of exploration in video games, I naturally sought out every golden idol. Each level contains usually 9 to 14 of them, hidden in out-of-the-way nooks, in awkward ledges, in acid, behind bars that are lifted by pressing a button, and so on. It's safe to say that locating and collecting these constituted the majority of my play time and that there would not be much game in their absence. Sadly, they are the only incentive for exploration, since the environments themselves reveal little to nothing of the meager story or the world (universe?) in which the game takes place and generally feature nothing noteworthy except some opportunities for screenshots. The golden idols also do not reveal more of the story, but they are not totally without value: as the player collects them, he unlocks developer commentary and notes for each of the stages as well as achievements. Still, I would have preferred some more game-related incentive for pursuing them, especially considering the time that went into doing so. It doesn't help that there are no in-game clues, whether subtle arrows or "proximity pings", to their locations, especially when they are hidden behind wall tiles that look like any other.

I have nothing bad to say about the other aspects of the game. The levels are large and well-designed. The art is lovely. The sound is just right and the unobtrusive music suits the game. The player can save at any time, including by quicksave; loading is quick; and any chapter can be replayed later. The options menu allows for decent customization of the experience. There is an optional "challenge mode" for each stage that involves using as few triangles as possible. Unfortunately, the parts of the game that I care about most just didn't meet my high expectations.

If you're looking for a puzzler, rewarding exploration, or a deep story, this game is probably not for you. If you're looking for a low-stakes, casual, (mostly) relaxing platformer with pleasant visuals, well-designed levels, and an interesting gameplay mechanic, consider buying it. Just be aware that, given what it is, you may feel that the game overstays its welcome if you try to fully complete all 16 chapters.

Despite the tone of my review, I would still say that I found the overall experience enjoyable enough to recommend it, especially given what I paid for it at a heavy discount. Considering the size of the development team and the lack of games of this quality in this genre as well, I give it a 7 out of 10. I look forward to this team's future work, which I hope will focus more on substance than style.
 
Skye
2,611 produits enregistrés
0

Recommandé
11.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 mai 2020
One of the few physics-based puzzles that truly push the bowndaries of player's perception of space.
Think The Witness meets Portal.

'Tri' stands for 'triangle'. Those you will draw in great numbers on walls and ceilings in order to walk on them.

The narrative is weak, but...
This color-scheme...
The construction of the levels...
The gravity-defying triangle-paved paths you draw across them...
The didjeridoo and Jew's harp-fuelled soundtrack...

The overall impression is so mystical. Like you're in a huge temple on a spiritual quest.

And you can do so many things with your triangles.

This is truly a wonderful game.
 
Orderly

TRI: Of Friendship and Madness

The soundtrack is great as it fits perfectly with the game. The story I wont touch as i havent finished it yet.

i highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a great puzzle game that will "give you a freedom of movement you've never experienced before"

Évaluation publiée le 6 janvier 2019
This is an incredibly good game. I honestly feel pretty sad that not many people have played it compared to similar games like Portal 2 or Antichamber.
This game feels a lot like Portal 2, but with mechanics created to break the game with. You go out of bounds? There's an idol there. Figure out you can place triangles on other triangles to create triangles basically anywhere (with enough time and effort)? That's intended, here's a puzzle where you need to do that.
Please, please buy this game. It's a great game, and I enjoyed every second of playing it.

Non recommandé
2.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 avril 2017
I bought TRI after adding it to my wishlist upon seeing a review which said it was highly underrated. Unfortunately, in my playing it I could not say the same. The biggest problem with this game is not the puzzles, but everything else:
- The narration is unbearably dry and uninteresting (contrast this was the witty humor of Portal that keeps you going, or the philosophical musings of The Talos Principle)
- The music is quite obnoxious (in my opinion)
- The graphics are simple geometric colored shapes (as you see in the video), unpleasant to view and navigate

While I'd like to give the puzzles in the game another shot, I think everything else in the game makes this one a no.

P.S. I also got quite frustrated with the puzzle's main mechanic, drawing a triangle by placing 3 points on the wall. The problem that this is too easy to exploit. Several times I was able to climb up some wall or corner by drawing triangle after triangle in an ad-hoc staircase that was obviously not intended by the game design. In this way you could solve many puzzles and get places you weren't supposed to, but it is not fun because you fall a lot and run into bugginess with the placement of triangles. The fact that it was possible at all frustrated me and made it harder to enjoy the puzzles (which didn't get very interesting in the time I played).
 
ospond
3
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
11.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 aout 2020
this has been one of the best first person puzzle game i've played in a long time, but before getting it in a bundle i hadn't heard of it. the main part of the game is focused on the ability to create triangles in the world that you can use to create platforms to get to higher areas to collect three keys to move to the next level, later these triangles get new abilities like being able to walk up walls and reflect light beams. there are 16 levels but the later ones took me an hour to complete with the puzzles involved being quite big and requiring some working out, however not so difficult that i needed to look up a wlkthrough (except one section at the end). these puzzles are quite clever but i think they could be spaced out a bit more so the player is not overwhelmed. it is possible to die in the game and i had times when i had to redo large segments cause i fell into acid or hit by a harmful laser. overall i highly recommend it (especially if you are a fan of the puzzles in portal) and feel the fact it hasn't had the aknowledgment and marketing to have it be well know is almost criminal.

Évaluation publiée le 11 novembre 2016
This game is a hidden gem, a must have if you like puzzle platform games.
The core mechanics are very interesting, and they will make you radically change the way you see the 3d space.
It has a nice Japanese flavour, and yes it's freaking difficult, some puzzles take more than an hour to solve. Maybe this is why I love it so much.

Pros:
-Beautiful visuals with a Japanese/zen atmosphere
-very difficult but mind-blowing puzzles

♥♥♥♥:
-very long puzzles (you must be very patient to beat the game)

Overall I think that this is one of the best games I have ever played, even if sometimes the story and the soundtrack are a bit odd (maybe that is part of its fascination too).

Recommandé
34.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 juin 2016
My Video Review:

Vidéo YouTube™: TRI: Of Friendship and Madness Review 
Vues : 1,200
Whoa, I did a video again. Places to buy TRI: http://store.steampowered.com/app/293660/TRI_Of_Friendship_and_Madness/ https://www.gog.com/game/tri http://tri-game.com/


Short summary:

TRI is an interesting puzzle game where you form triangles on walls to solve puzzles. The twist being that you'll eventually be able to walk on walls and redirect light and lasers with them. This is where I wholeheartedly recommended only half of TRI to some of you because while reflecting the lasers with your triangles sounds like a great idea on paper, in reality it can lead to a lot of pixel perfect placement that's more tedious than fun, especially in the later levels that revolve almost exclusively around this mechanic. Still, the mechanics and level design are pushed to their absolute creative limits here which lead to a lot of fun and intriguing "Aha!" moments.

TRI has a challenging difficulty curve that isn't afraid to present you with the seemingly impossible the further you play on. Also worth mentioning is the extremely appealing, simplistic artstyle and truly memorable soundtrack that accompanies this game. They really nailed TRI on the presentation side of things. A cute fox will follow you as you solve progressively harder puzzles while this light hearted chanting goes on in the background, and there's just something really enchanting and relaxing about that.

At it's best, TRI stands out strong in the puzzle genre right now. Even at it's worst, its still worth playing for any puzzler fan.
 
Campion

6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
9 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante

Recommandé
25.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 juin 2015
I have never before played a puzzle game as long as an RPG in my life. But damn it if I didn't love my time with this game! Even when I spent possibly two hours on one of the "expert" puzzles, I found the game enticing from beginning to end.

Warnings!

  • This game is HARD. It will force you to think differently in order to beat this game's puzzles. Most challenges are for experts, but even the main puzzles are no simple matter.
  • I do not recommend this game to be played with a controller. You spend a lot of time drawing up triangles, and in later levels you will have to micromanage each one.
  • Turn down the triangle-textures as you're going to draw a lot of them. Your performance will improve greatly.

Mechanics

What is TRI? TRI is a FPS puzzle-platformer that combines a single main-mechanic throughout the whole experience (after you find the TRI in Chapter/Level 3) a la Portal and the unreal, illogical world of Antichamber.

There are some platforming skills at your disposal such as climbing edges by holding the jump button or climbing into holes by holding both the jump and the crouch button. This last mechanic can be picky at times, but you can get by with climbing and crouching throughout most of the game.

The execution of this game makes me wish a game would utilize Mirror's Edge controls with an interesting game mechanic for speedrunners to make puzzles both challenging in reflexes and in the thought process.

Unlike games such as QUBE and Magnrunner Pulse, you are allowed to draw triangles on just about every surface, except wood. You gain an ability later to scale triangles on walls and later to bounce light on triangles. Afterwards, the game is at your whim for how you want to go around the levels.

This greatly improves the replayability as you can challenge yourself to find alternative paths or be more efficient with your triangles and time.

Despite how difficult I've said the game is at some parts, the game scales its difficulty fairly throughout the first ten or so chapters. After Chapter 10, you better have mastered drawing triangles because you're going to draw a lot.

Each new chapter introduces something new that you have to experiment with to figure out what is going on, and some stages might be more expansive than others or more laybrinth-like.

The goal of every stage is to collect three red fox statues to open the portal to the next level. These can be tracked with waypoints by pressing the highligh key (H). There are also secret golden idols in every level that require you to either explore every aspect of the level, look more closely at the level, or challenge you to take the harder challenges.

These golden idols unlock some developer commentary, prototype pics, level layout pics, etc. But the real reward for these idols is the challenge of 100% the levels by finding all the secret and the super secret idols. The downside is that too many rely on visual-illusions that you might grow tired of quickly.

Narrative (No spoilers)

The story is about the Monk, Blue and Red (the Old God Foxes). You are just some human disciple of the Monk, and there's no backstory behind your character.

I don't think this is much of a spoiler because the game never really cares about who you are, only about the world and the other characters. (Even in the developers' commentary, they said they scrapped the idea of giving you a backstory because it wasn't worth it).

The Monk can be thought of as your GLaDoS, but he won't make quips at your failures; he'll be your source of exposition and some encouragement. I don't think his VA is bad at all, but if you're expecting some rich character like GLaDos, I think you'll be disappointed.

After every other level, you'll recieve a cutscene that gives some more exposition. The twist of the game is somewhat expected a mile away, but the story is servicable and I quite like the narrative. This game is a case of more style and gameplay over story substance.

The only gripe I have with the story is I don't quite like how the game handles the idea of madness; it treats the matter as a temporary condition rather than a permanent affliction.

Now I'm not one to not encourage more happier endings, but I think the developers missed out on the opportunity to flesh out the idea of friendship and of madness in treating both things with more consequences. It's something I think this game could've easily done better.

But it's clear the game wanted to focus more on making a relaxing, mind-bending puzzle game than a serious story.

Best Experience--Reccomendation

As I mentioned beforehand, in order to complete 100% of every level, you need to find all the golden idols. I would recommend at least being a completionist for the first ten levels/chapters.

Each of these extra challenges will make you more accustomed to the game's mechanics and they will get your head around some of the possibilities you can do. The secrets are not artificial time-wasters; they give you a better opportunity to explore every aspect of the level and become familiar with the TRI.

If you're tired of going after the idols by chapter 9 or 10, stick with collecting the red fox statues. If you think you can handle more mental strain, go for the long run and try to 100% the game.

Pros & ♥♥♥♥ Summary

Pros
  • THE SOUNDTRACK! If you love Rayman, boy do I have the soundtrack for you.
  • A difficult puzzle game.
  • Simple, yet frustratingly deceptive mechanics and puzzles.
  • Lots of content to get out of this game.
  • Foxes, foxes, foxes, and vulpes gods.
  • Simple story for young and old.
  • Beautiful scenary and very thought-out level design.

♥♥♥♥
  • A difficult puzzle game. Frustration in the later part of the game with the golden idols. (Chapter 10 onwards)
  • Crouch Button + Jump Button = NOT FUN
  • Too many visual illusion puzzles and one-time kind of puzzles.
  • Simple narrative and characters.
  • Nuances with drawing triangles over the simplicity of the Portal gun.
  • Some levels feel way too big or take too long to navigate.
 
Brian (The Schmaltzy Cynic)
1,438 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
9.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 janvier 2021
TRI: Of Friendship and Madness est probablement un jeu sous-côté qui mérite pourtant, à mon sens, sa place aux côtés de Portal et The Talos Principle dans le genre des puzzle-games en vue à la première personne !

Attention je n'ai pas fini le jeu (j'en suis a priori à un peu plus de la moitié) et j'ai atteint le point où la difficulté grandissante des niveaux / puzzles m'impose de ne progresser que par portions de niveaux (à chaque niveau il faut trouver trois statues de renards pour débloquer le niveau suivant, il y a aussi plusieurs statues plus petites à collecter par niveau qui débloquent des succès et des petits contenus additionnels).

Dans TRI on dessine des triangles dont les trois pointes doivent toucher des surfaces en pierre (sols, murs & plafonds, le bois ne fonctionne pas) formant une surface (enfin, deux puisqu'il y a deux faces formellement) qui est "adhésive" pour peu qu'elle forme un plan dont la pente n'est pas trop éloignée (dans les 30 ° je dirais) de celle du plan sur lequel on se situe... généralement le sol, mais puisqu'on peut passer d'un triangle dessiné à un autre on se retrouve rapidement à se déplacer sur les murs & plafonds ce qui permet d'atteindre des passages normalement inaccessibles et d'actionner divers leviers etc. Les graphismes sont plutôt simples (et mignons) mais permettent d'assurer une relativement bonne lisibilité des niveaux (parfois assez labyrinthiques) aux ambiances "japonisantes", le tout accompagné d'une bande son correcte (pas très variée, mais elle ne me tape pas sur les nerfs). Le fait d'avoir une relative liberté de mouvements (sols, murs & plafonds, mais aussi course, sauts et position accroupie pour passer dans certains réduits) avec des passages assez aériens (mention spéciale au niveau 8) en vue à la première personne peut induire de la nausée et des sensations de vertige, mais TRI a l'élégance de proposer pas mal de personnalisations au niveau des contrôles, du FOV et du roulis ce qui devrait permettre à chacun de trouver son bonheur (avec un FOV large et un roulis au maximum les sensations de course sont particulièrement convaincantes & les déplacements au plafond au-dessus du vide sont eux-aussi très prenants) !

Avec sa petite quinzaine de niveaux et ses nombreux secrets optionnels à trouver le contenu est généreux autant pour ceux qui voudraient terminer le jeu simplement que pour ceux qui voudraient tenter le 100 % !

Tourne comme un charme sous Linux (Kubuntu 20.04, Nvidia pilotes propriétaires) ! :)
 
Riusma

Recommandé
9.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 décembre 2014
3D探索型の一人称視点アクションゲーム。字幕やゲーム内UIが日本語対応の安心仕様です。
　外敵との戦闘行為は一切ありません。単独で仕掛けを読み解いてゆくのはPortalをイメージする方も多いと思います。オリエンタルな雰囲気の背景やBGMがクセになる人もいるのではないでしょうか。
　はじめは自分で三角形の足場を作ることしかできませんが、話を進めるにしたがって形成した三角形の上をさも重力の方向が変わったかのように歩くことができるようになります。文字での説明を見るよりもまずは2本のトレイラームービーを見てしまうことをおすすめします。ゲーム内で備わる能力はこの2種類だけで、あとはマップとのにらめっこに時間を費やすことになるでしょう。各マップともによく作りこんであって退屈することがありません。
　ただしその反面、マップが広すぎて歩いてる時間が長く感じることもあります。また、進行上必須なルートが「通常の壁と全く変わらない見た目をした動かせるブロック」で閉じられている箇所もあって不親切に感じる箇所もありました。動かせるブロックはカーソルを合わせたときにアイコンが変化するということを覚えておくとよいかもしれません。
　また、他のどのゲームよりも酔いやすいように感じます。設定→カメラからスムーズとふらつきを0%、視野を広めに設定、ノイズオーバーレイをオフにすることでだいぶ緩和されるので、特にスムーズとふらつきは最初に設定しておくとよいでしょう。
　総じて一人称視点の探索ゲームとしてはかなり出来が良い部類だと思います。日本語の空耳が頭から離れない…血まみれマンボウ
 
Oretachi
1
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
17.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 juillet 2015
It's a good game. Tris, the main game mechanic, is creative, original and fun to use. Graphic stylisation is fantastic and so is the level design. The first half of the game has been a blast to play.
But... Had the game ended in chapter 10 I would have been much more positive. In the remaining six chapters the difficulty ramps up to the point where I had to regularly check walkthroughs because I had no idea what to do. The levels are confusing, huge and non linear, there are no hints on how the puzzles work and what is expected from you. From time to time the game introduces some new mechanic with no explanation whatsoever (solid light beams, foxes etc). And even if you know the solution it's still pretty hard to do it because millimeter precision is expected from you when placing the triangles. During chapter 15 this got so ridiculously frustrating I've almost rage quit the game for good.
 
Petr Stránský

Évaluation publiée le 27 septembre 2016
meine spielzeit: 1084,32 Minuten.
ich denke, das ist ein hübscher zeitvertreib xD
Das Spiel ist super. insgesamt 16 Kapitel, bei denen man über selbst "gemalte" Dreiecke sich seine Wegfindung schaffen muss. Abgerundet wird das ganze durch Laser + Spiegel, Kisten sowie kleinere und große Rätsel. Und für die Erfolgsjäger gibts natürlich auch versteckte Gegenstände, die sich "Idole" schimpfen.
Grafisch und Soundtechnisch gibts nichts zu jammern. Es ist auf fantasy - comic Stil gehalten und das ist bei diesem Spiel auch gut so. Der Soundtrack hat etwas beruhigendes an sich. Auch passend für ein Spiel, bei dem man genau genommen nie stirbt. Falls man es doch mal schafft, spawnt man 10 Schritte von dem Ort, wo man umgekippt ist.

Kurz gesagt. Ein Spiel, das auf lange sicht Spaß gemacht hat. :)

Recommandé
39.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 novembre 2016
Tri is a firsr person puzzle game with exploration as well, when you get the gravity shifting ability to walk on walls, it's easy to explore a lot and the light reflect upgrade is very good too but a litle hard to get precise reflections.

The maps all vary and have different feels and have many idols to collect too, The puzzles are not just 'place a tri on the wall ands climb it', they vary with using boxes, switches and light beams, white is harmless but stay out of red.

it is nice to see what ideas the developers originally had for the game and how it has progressed.

I do have 1 warning for it, when you get the gravity shifting, you may get a bit of motion sickness as this is quite a lot topo look at.

Overall I would recommend this game because it allows you to an extent make your own paths to move on.
Maybe if the developers ever made a Tri 2 it would be nice to see more mechanics, As this is now is very playable and enjoyable, I recommend having a look around the rooms first before you solve anything.
 
Bubblegum Cuddly Dragoness

Évaluation publiée le 16 octobre 2022
From the videos I thought this was a platformer, but seeing how much Portal inspiration it has I was am even happier to have played it! I am so tired of cheap Portal wannabes but Tri feels very original and with a heavy element of exploration involved. It can be cumbersome to set up the infrastructure the first time going somewhere but towards the end of the stage the pathways created make it easier to get around and eventually find the solution. Music isn't bad either, good experience overall.

Évaluation publiée le 19 janvier 2018
謎題非常豐富的遊戲
謎題重複性非常低，要完成收集非常的難(有些收集品的位置實在太...)
遊戲難度調整的很好，愈來愈難，愈來愈難，愈來愈難，他X的有夠難
但是大概第10關之後的難度令我無言，因為這個難度是來自於我不知道要幹麻
比如我遇到謎題時，我不知道這個是要直接過(畫三角形、搬東西)，還是現在過不了(等一下再來)，又或是要到各處收集物品(一起拿過來再過)
遊戲中並沒有清楚的提示，然後我只好逛地圖，晃2圈還是找(想)不出來要做啥
於是第8關開始到結束，我每關都得看攻略影片才知道要做什麼
而且第13關開始，我覺有些設計玩起來不有趣，是刁難
所以最後幾個小時我的遊戲體驗並不好
不過這仍然是個很好的解謎遊戲
喔，容易3D暈眩的人就別玩了，這遊戲的視角從頭轉到尾
推薦指數 88

2.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 octobre 2014
I've always been a fan of first person puzzle games ever since Portal. Since then, I've tried to play all of them from titles like Qbeh-1 to Path to Thalimus and I have to say, TRI has impressed me a lot more than most. The story line is pretty decent but the thing that really impressed me the most were the puzzles. You get to create these triangle sheilds that can be used as many things from platforms to mirrors that reflect light, all adding several possibilites to completing most the temples(Test Chambers) and finding all the secrets, and if you're into these types of games, I'm sure you're gonna want to find all the secrets and the exploration really makes you use your imagination when it comes to completing a temple 100%. There is also scores for best times and least triangles used, a great feature that adds to the replayability of the game. I remember playing portal and trying to get the least amount of portals as I could and the hours I spent doing it. I'm sure that will follow with this game as well. The only feature that I think could make this any better would be some type of 2 player online coop, but even without it, it's great fun. I definitely recommend picking this up if you're into these types of games, you won't be dissapointed. Oh and did I mention the graphics feel like a magical cell shaded deep space minecraft :)

Vidéo YouTube™: TRI: Of Friendship and Madness | Review & Gameplay 
Vues : 2,883
Tri on Steam - http://store.steampowered.com/app/293660/ --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Be sure to Subscribe if you like the Content!

2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 juin 2018
Tri a gem of triagular perfection, where you do more with a few triangles than you ever expected. Given the texts, screenshots and Portal comparisons one may expect a game of similar challenges but different tools (triangles instead of portals). Given the success of Portal this is fair enough but here I will talk about where Tri goes above and beyond the expectations of a "Portal with triangles". 1. Compared to Portal, Tri is very non linear. Instead of working from puzzle to puzzle and room to room you have to consider the whole 3-dimensional construct of the level. You are usually free to choose which of the statues to collect first and there are multiple solutions to many puzzles. 2. The Tri is so much more powerful than the portal gun. You can fill the Level with insane numbers of triangles and create elaborate constructs to achieve your goals. The Tri allows you to achieve anything thinkable... and the game requires you to think it. 3. While Portal is already known for requiring a lot of 3-dimensional thinking Tri pushes this to a whole new level. You don't just have to consider position and momentum in 3D-space you need to consider the level in many wildly rotated states to think your way to the harder to reach places. Tri requires you to truly change your perspective. 4. Again contrary to Portal this game offers so much to do beyond completing the levels. In Tri there are so many Idols to find in the most unimaginable and unreachable places. Often you wonder if it is at all possible to reach a certain spot ... and when you finally do there is an Idol waiting. Someone actually expected you to get there! To appreciate the true genius of the level design you must push yourself to collect as many idols as you can. Now don't get me wrong, I'm not trying to say that Portal is a worse game than Tri. It's just that Tri has unique qualities that can't be underappreciated.
 
ntroPi

[tr][td][h1]Difficulty[td]The solutions are really simple. Executing the solution will seem impossible. [tr][td][h1]Replayability[td]Not really. [tr][td][h1]Fun[td]The first half is fun, the second half is madness.

25.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 novembre 2016
Sabe aquele jogo, que tem editor de level, e você pode criar suas fases do jeito que quiser, e quando você ♥♥♥♥ para um amigo seu completar a fase ele não consegue por ser muito difícil/mal feito? Aí você mostra pra ele como completa a fase e ele fala que não gostou/achou ruim? Esse jogo é um monte de fase desse tipo. As fases desse jogo não são divertidas. Ao meu ver, elas são muito chatas e massantes. Não que os quebra-cabeças sejam ruins, mas não são divertidos de completar, na maioria das vezes. Os colecionáveis são a pior parte ao meu ver: Tem alguns muito dificeis de achar e não é recompensante achar os mesmo. Você precisa ficar atento a pequenos detalhes e alguns são horríveis de conseguir pegar mesmo sabendo onde eles estão. Inicialmente eu pensei "Como esse jogo não é mais conhecido?" pois a proposta é bem interessante. Agora, a cada fase que eu tento completar eu penso "Já entendi porque esse jogo não é bem conhecido".

21.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 novembre 2017
Very satisfying puzzle game. Be warned, the mechanics may seem overly simplistic for the first level or two, and I might even venture to say *boring*, but by the third or fourth stage the game quickly reveals its depth. By mid-game, the difficulty reaches a very appropriate level. In addition to the puzzles, the graphics and art-style are very surreal and the level design is incredible. The game was quite long as well, for the price. It took me about 20 hours to complete - that was with finding about 2/3 of the hidden collectables.

Recommandé
42.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 février 2018
Just finished playing one of the hardest platform puzzlers I've experienced in a long time. It is really challenging, but in a good way! If you like to exercise the 3D part of your brain then you're going to enjoy this. The first few levels are a bit of a runaround, but don't let that fool you into thinking it's all a walk in the park. This game is a few years old now, so isn't expensive. I got nearly 40 hours out of it, so it's well worth it!

Once you get the Tri that changes your orientation on triangles that you create, the whole game comes to life. Sometimes you forget which way is up - that's an interesting way to plummet to doom! I highly recommend that right from the start you follow the 'side quest' of finding the idols in each level. You can complete the game without finding a single one, but it's a great challenge!

Really loved this game!!!

4.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 avril 2016
Это игра от иллюминатов... не менее)) Симулятор треугольника, самой простой геометрической фигуры.
На деле, данный проект представляет из себя этакий логический платформер от первого лица, с уровнями-головоломками. На каждом уровне спрятаны по три статуи лисицы (да-да, в игре много слов посвящено именно этим хитрецам), которые нужно разместить на трёх платформах у пьедестала, на котором активируется портал на следующий уровень. И чем дальше - тем больше и сложнее уровень. Чем дальше, тем шире возможности главного героя. Чем ближе к финалу, тем сильнее вскипает мозг (псс-с, признаюсь по секрету, я так и не осилил игру до финала).
Игра крайне рекомендуется всем фанатам жанра, а так же любителям игр с необычной визуализацией, нестандартным геймплеем и обладателям нестандартного мышления... ну и почитателям лисичек, разумеется!
 
LORD KAIN

2.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 novembre 2014
TRI est un excellent jeu d’aventure au design, à la musique, au graphisme envoutants

L’histoire de TRI est assez subtile mais elle est en parfaite harmonie avec le jeu.

Vous vous retrouvez, on ne sait comment, dans un monde à part, le monde des Dieux. Un prêtre vous attend. Il va vous accompagner tout le long de votre aventure en vous donnant des indices et des conseils.

Il ne vous raconte pas grand chose, ce prêtre. C’est à vous d’en apprendre plus en découvrant des idoles. En avançant dans l’histoire, vous découvrirez les tenants et les aboutissants.

Votre personnage va acquérir des pouvoirs. Le premier est la possibilité de créer des plateformes triangles qui vous permettront de naviguer dans l’espace.

Pour découvrir l’ensemble des mes impressions sur TRI.[www.graal.fr]

10.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 décembre 2014
I love this game. It is and excellent puzzler with a lot to offer.

The levels slowly grow in size and complexity and the player has free roam of anywhere they are clever enough to get to. The atmosphere is great, and the music does just enough to fill the void in a less is more kinda way. For being a very relaxing game, the puzzles can tend to take a lot out of me and I will rarely complete more than one or two levels in a sitting. Getting the necessary pieces each level can be done relatively quickly but I really enjoy just exploring and poking around for those hidden idols.

The levels are full of puzzles ranging from simple to dubiously clever. I believe this game has gratified me with more "look at how clever I am" moments than perhaps any other.

I would highly recommend this to anyone looking for a good mental exercize.

Évaluation publiée le 29 juin 2019
I really wanted to like this game. The aesthetic, though simple, is pleasant. The soundtrack is nice. The story isn't great, but it's serviceable. Unfortunately there are simply better platform puzzlers out there. One should also be aware that this game gave me motion sickness even after disabling head bobble and increasing the FOV--the only other game that has done this to me was Everybody's Gone to the Rapture. The sensation increased when the gravity-defying puzzles were introduced. While the puzzle ideas were unique, this game just wasn't for me. If you don't easily get motion sick, you might enjoy it more than I did.

Great innovative gameplay. It's similar to Trine that you can create your own platform. And similar to Trine there might be intened solutions to problems but you can also just spam create triangles to get over there.

The dev commentary states that they had more indepth story planned but ditched it later on, which is a shame since that is the area the game is kinda lacking. Also the narrator voice actor kinda sucks.

Good game overall.

1,123 produits enregistrés

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
