Recommandé
15.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 mars 2023
TRI is a mixed bag, but a mixed bag worth your time. In terms of first-person puzzle games, there's few to none that ever meet the bar that Portal set. TRI, however, manages to occasionally reach that lofty height when it isn't getting in its own way. Divided into 15 separate chapters, TRI's quality is heavily dependent on when in the game you're currently at. You can group these chapters into a couple of distinct 'worlds' that each focus on different mechanics, and its these mechanics and their prevalence that causes highs and lows in how enjoyable the game is.

"World 1" is simple but effective, teaching you the basics and giving some good puzzles with the surprisingly expansive ability to create triangles. There's secrets to be found, the pacing is good, and it's easy to believe that the whole game could be built around the concepts within. After all, being able to create your own platforms and walls basically everywhere is quite powerful, and for a dedicated player it's possible to find your way to the far reaches of every level. The game even rewards these exploits! I thought at this point that later levels would be working around limiting this concept.

Then, in "World 2," your power expands to the point that your previous ability looks downright pathetic in comparison. Apologies for the repeated comparison, but this is the 'getting the second portal gun' moment, except it came as a total surprise for me. Your new ability to change gravity using your triangles completely changes both how you build and how you view the environment, and the way it works is done in a way that feels smooth and natural. For the next 4 levels, the game is at a peak in quality. It reaches that perfect, trance-like state where you're thinking in an exhilarating, alien way that only the best of these kinds of games can ever induce. I was utterly shocked that a game that went this far under the radar could be this incredible.

...Unfortunately, it wasn't. "World 3," begins, and the game discards much of its strengths. It's not bad, I'd say quality-wise that "World 3" and "World 1" are roughly equal, but coming down from the high that the previous levels gave to the very rote, well-trodden light-redirection puzzles "World 3" focuses on is jarring. Especially since this is also when you start to be able to die in levels, which is handled... more than a little awkwardly. Much of the worst of it has since been smoothed out by patches, but the respawn system never feels elegant. Again, "World 3" is still fun enough, but unlike the previous levels, its a quality that feels like it could just as easily be found elsewhere. Light-redirection puzzles have been a thing since the N64 Zeldas, so it's difficult to make them interesting nowadays. I was hoping that this would be the low point of the game.

"World 4" is the low point of the game. It's all based around an abstracted form of the light-redirection puzzles of before called "Kami," and it's taught poorly. There's only 2 levels here, but the first one took forever for me simply because the rules of how the "Kami" move are entirely vague. In practice, you wind up just bouncing them along a seemingly preset path that you have to clumsily work out through trial and error. It's "World 3" with no freedom. In addition, the levels themselves become very closed-off, feeling much more restrictive than the levels of worlds previous. And unfortunately, that's all that can really be said about these 2 levels, they're only notable for how frustrating and tedious they are. I was worried that the game would continue this downward trend in quality.

Well, leave it to TRI to surprise me once more, because inexplicably, "World 5" manages to shoot all the way back up to "World 2's" level. When the game busts out it's most challenging levels, it manages to shine once more. They're long, difficult, and mentally taxing, but in an incredibly rewarding way. I haven't mentioned it thus far, but the progression system, having to find 3 totems and place them at a designated exit, works incredibly well for marathon levels, feeling like chipping away at a much more massive puzzle. You wind up using everything you learned in the last 4 worlds, plus play with a couple of extra gimmicks that are much more interesting than the ones introduced previously. Level 15 in particular is so good that it's the only time I went and found every single secret on during my first playthrough, despite the difficulty. Now, I will say that the very last puzzle of the finale winds up being kinda dumb and poorly conveyed (to the point that it was the only one I needed a walkthrough for) thanks to one bad audio cue, but I can let that slide given just how good everything else was.

So... that's TRI. Just like the player, it goes all over the place, leaving no peak or crevasse unseen. Does this mean that the game averages out to being just okay? Maybe by some perspectives, but I think that the one-of-a-kind quality of TRI at its best far outdoes the very standard issues that TRI at its worst runs into. Statistically, 10 of the 15 levels are excellent, and only 2 of the 5 levels remaining are ones I would say are truly bad. The game has a unique aesthetic and a decent story, even if it isn't the most well-told. I think it's worth anyone's time, as when everything in the game comes together, there's nothing else like it.
 
JustAWord
0

Évaluation publiée le 8 janvier 2021
Navigating through mazes, figuring out how to get 'over there', made all the more challenging despite the ability to create ramps and platforms almost anywhere. Turn the world upside down, and bounce lasers as you please. Plus the hidden idols can be quite tricky to find. The biggest downside to this game for me, is the sparse story. Maxter Max
1,843 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
37.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 décembre 2020
TRI is very much a puzzle platformer with some unique mechanics and indie development style. I don't usually write reviews but I've really fallen in love with it over the years, played it for a while some time ago, got to some of the more open, difficult stages, and stopped for a while before playing it once more and completing it. I have a dumb fear about open spaces and gravity flipping stuff so that stonewalled me for a long while, but I'm glad I came back to TRI. It stuck with me in a good way, and now I'm going for a 100% collection of the idols since I finished the main story. :D

I like the unlockable bonus things, bits of art and development stuff, as well as the developer commentary tracks (though I do wish they had subtitles! Just a minor issue.) The devs, Jana Reinhardt and Friedrich Hanisch, put a lot of heart into TRI and I enjoy listening to them talk about it, as well as the soundtrack. Shoutouts to King Ludi (Ludwig Hanisch) for the work on the music, it's got a strange, world folky feel and the guy is a total sweetheart in an email I sent asking for lyrics to one of the Special tracks (though he's been out of music making for a while, into painting now, bless).

I wasn't too sure about some aspects of the art style at first but admittedly it grew on me, and it intentionally doesn't detract from the main aspect of the game - Puzzles, and many of them. Navigating the areas alone can sometimes be a challenge, but once you have the hang of it there's a certain good feeling to mastering the tool the game gives you and using it to treat walls and ceilings as prospective 'flooring', gravity and all. Aside from enviroments there are also an abundance of other challenges that really ended up reminding me of other first person puzzlers like Portal and such. You got your standard game crates, your lightbeam shenanigans, platforming, etc, but the titular TRI artifact and the triangles you learn to traverse the levels with are the real core of the fun, especially along with bonus artifacts if you're the sort of gamer that likes to treasure hunt for cleverly hidden secrets.

TRI isn't exactly a fast paced fps and has no enemies or jumpscares. It's methodical, with a clean artstyle and some easy to understand, challenging to master game elements combined with increasingly detailed and warped level design in a funky little geometrical world. But if anyone read this far, here are some tips:

1. Mazes can be confusing, but you'll be given a tool early on capable of making a limitless number of triangles for platforms, paths, and MARKERS. If you're like me and have a trash sense of direction, make little symbols and marks for yourself to keep track of what is where.

2. At some point in a later level you will come across a large circular room. It's hard to explain, but there will be objects flying out of a spawner just outside of that room. The goal is to bounce those objects through the circular path and into the receptacle along it. Yes, it is a long way and yes, the flight path of the object can be...questionable at times. I was stuck here for a while because it seemed like an unreasonable thing to expect the player to do, but it was the right answer. Oh well.

3. This becomes crucial later on. If SOMETHING, like a sliding block, breaks any of the triangles you put down then it will break ALL of the triangles connected in a 'chain' to the one it breaks. So if you have a long path painstakingly set up, make sure nothing will break it! Or make a path out of triangles that are a little further apart - they don't have to be touching directly for you to stick to them, just close enough.

Alright, it's late and that's all I got. There's a very, VERY simple story to this thing, and lots of puzzley (rarely janky) goodness and platforming gravity flippery. I dig it, maybe you will too, who knows. IMO, great game, pretty good replay value if you're the type to 100% it. Have fun!
 
Hex
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
35.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 février 2020
TRI: Of Friendship and Madness caught my attention when it was first released, mainly because of its artsyle and central theme around foxes. And it quickly became a game I got hooked on. The game has a simple premise, draw triangles and collect idols. But as you progress, even this simple task becomes ridiculously hard, with triangles gaining the ability to alter gravity and reflect light. After a while, you grasp that the game wants you to think outside the box and encourages you to do it with the Idols of Unnecessary Knowledge.

The game's unique artstyle really helps with the gameplay as well, as nearly everything is divided into 1x1x1 grid structure. TRI's storyline is not something to behold, but a cute one which flows with the game. The music is spectacular and fits the atmosphere of the game so well, that I am pretty sure the game could not deliver the same atmosphere if the soundtrack was different. Even though I admit some of the puzzles are rather a burden, requiring more time to place the triangles correctly rather than finding the solution, this game was one of the best experiences I had. And at this time where first person spatial tinkering is rather rare, TRI carves itself a good place in this somewhat niche category. I bought this game on sale, but it is worth the entire place in my opinion, as I later bought the OST and artbook to further support the developers.

Overall, TRI delivers a surreal experience with foxes as Odd Gods, tribal chanting music, and a space-time bending artefact in the shape of a triangle. It hasn't got that much of a replay value if you are not an achievement hunter, but it is hell of a fun to think outside the box for the gametime it offers. I think it can be bought even at full price, but it is, again in my opinion, a must-buy when it is on sale if you are into this type of three-dimensional exploration and experimentation.
 
Lifalif'in Çıtır Yulafı
244 produits enregistrés
0

TRI, un jeu particulier.
Au début tout va, c'est coloré, le but du jeu est simple à comprendre, mais c'est après que tout se complique. Ce jeu retourne un peu la tête tant les capacités nécessaires pour grimper, sans tomber, et récupérer tous les items de chaque level. Bonne expérience mais attention toute fois, le jeu n'est pas si facile qu'il en à l'air, plus d'un en seront découragé.

Évaluation publiée le 28 décembre 2019
This game is so pleasant as a 3d platformer puzzle game. With a little more polish on textures and audio, I would consider this game to be as good as Portal 1. I was quite impressed with the gameplay and the mechanics. Much like portal, you are given an ability to generate things to help you progress through the levels. Just when you get used to how things work, they upgrade your abilities to really increase the challenge in between levels. The story is also neat, and I like the atmosphere of mystery that comes of it.

Absolutely Get this game it is worth the money for sure!

Évaluation publiée le 6 janvier 2018
9.0/10

Lindo Jogo! Não há muito que se possa criticar. É um jogo de puzzle que te força a pensar fora da caixa, com uma arte incrível. Recomendo para quem gostou de Portal, porque tem uma pegada parecida.

*Recomendo para os que forem jogar, ir atrás dos ídolos de ouro, acrescenta em muito a quantidade de puzzles.

PROS:
  • Gráficamente bonito.
  • Cores que criam uma atmosfera.
  • Jogo leve. Os gráficos rodam suavemente.
  • História muito interessante e cativante.
  • Gimmick incrível! Cria um estilo de jogo incentivando a criatividade do jogador.

CONTRAS:
  • Senti falta de mais Lore. Amei a história e queria mais sobre os Odd Gods.
 
Lasagna
521 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
5.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 avril 2016
I bought TRI on a sale, presuming that it would not run on my pc but too intriguing to pass up. Despite not being compatible with my graphics chip, it runs perfectly smoothly in a window (I haven't yet tried full screen)

The music is engaging, drawing you into the intense fantasy realm the game is set in, and I found myself pleased and eager to hunt for this missing Fox. I did have to adjust the music often depending how long a puzzle area was, as it gets louder the closer you are to an objective. I did not get tired of it once.

The visuals are just gorgeous, and loved the designs, it pops and is literal magic with the vibrant colors imo

The puzzles are very hide-and-seek, and remind me a lot of FEZ: easy going but challenging if you wish to find everything. You have a time, if you are a speed runner, and enough hidden items to make it fun for completionists. I am pleased that the bonus material is on a collection system for the overall game instead of per level.

I already agree with the guide: the power to create triangles both drives you to wonder and madness
 
warpendragn
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
21.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 septembre 2016
A darn good puzzle game.
It's in a somewhat similar vein as Antichamber, but it does its own thing and does it quite well.

The first couple levels grant you the power to be a triangle god and you feel a rush of freedom thinking that you can go anywhere and do anything, but the game throws reasonable and well-thought-out restrictions your way: triangles have a maximum length per side, you need proper angles to use their gravity-warping feature, can't draw in mid-air without another triangle base, can't draw on wood, etc.

The style is nice to look at and the story is minimal yet nice to have.

I had to look up puzzle answers in the game's steam forums a couple times. (A large box can go on two buttons at once.) But still the game as a whole was very satisfying. I'll probably revisit it later and try to get more optional statues and enable audio commentary.
 
Leonhard Euler

Rouge Sable
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
26.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 février 2015
TRI: Of Friendship and Madness

Już dawno szukałem jakiejś gry z solidnymi zagadkami, które potrafiłyby rozgrzać moje zwoje mózgowie. Na podstawie zwiastunów uznałem, że TRI może być grą która wpasuje się w to wymaganie. Nie pomyliłem się.

W dużym skrócie - zostajesz wezwany do pewnej świątyni żeby pomóc mnichowi przywrócić zdrowie psychiczne pewnemu bóstwu. Będziesz to robić przemierzając 16 poziomów najeżonymi zagadkami i dużą liczbą trójkątów :P Grafika? Ładna, schludna, pasująca do tematyki (religie wschodu), ale nie każdemu musi pasować taki styl (polecam obejrzeć jakiś "Let's play"). Muzyka doskonale buduje nastrój (śpiewy mnichów, melodie inspirowane muzyką orientalną). Fabuła? Jest tylko tłem do wydarzeń, więc nie oczekujcie zbyt wiele.

W całym tym wewnętrznym świecie przyjdzie nam spotkać jedynie duchową postać mnicha i nikogo więcej. Nie ma żadnej narracji więc poza 2-3 linijkami tekstu jakie wypowiada mnich w każdej rundzie oraz animowanymi przerywnikami odsłaniającymi pewne wydarzenia z przeszłości nie ma w grze żadnych dialogów. Czy to źle? Mi nie przeszkadzało, w końcu przybyłem do świątyni rozwiązywać zagadki a nie dyskutować.

Właśnie, zagadki - te są zróżnicowane, zwłaszcza że narzędzie jakie otrzymamy do ich rozwiązywania posiada różne możliwości, które odkryte zostaną przed nami wraz z postępem rozgrywki, co tym samym wprowadzi nowe rodzaje zagadek. Niektóre z zagadek są banalne a niektóre spędzą wam sen z powiek :P W dodatku pewne moce które z czasem otrzymamy pozwalają nam czasem rozwiązać zagadki w sposób inny niż domyślnie przewidywali to autorzy gry :D

W każdej rundzie poukrywane są złote figurki, których zdobywanie pozwoli nam odblokować dodatkową zawartość, typu komentarze autorów, wstępne zarysy gry, concept arty itd. Całkiem ciekawe materiały, niestety odblokowałem tylko połowę bo figurki są pochowane nie raz tak dobrze, że więcej czasu zajęłoby mi ich szukanie niż rozwiązane zagadek w danym poziomie.

Wiele mógłbym jeszcze pisać o TRI, zdecydowanie jedna z lepszych gier poświęcona rozwiązywaniu zagadek z widoku pierwszej osoby. Spokojnie można ją postawić obok takich perełek jak Portal 1 i 2 czy Ether One.

Ocena końcowa: 8+/10

Plusy:
+ zagadki (zróżnicowanie, poziom trudności, itd.)
+ możliwości narzędzia do rozwiązywania zagadek
+ bardzo zróżnicowane lokacje
+ grafika
+ muzyka
+ dużo dodatkowej treści
+ złote idole - wyzwanie samo w sobie

Minusy:
- (opcjonalnie) brak interakcji
- (opcjonalnie) szczątkowa fabuła
- (opcjonalnie) brak pomocy (np. podpowiedzi) dla osób nie obytych z zagadkami
- niedokładność silnika fizyki
- niektóre zagadki są bezmyślne (nie chcę tutaj zdradzać zawczasu)
- takie sobie zakończenie
 
Leaffar
3,392 produits enregistrés
0

Évaluation publiée le 3 janvier 2021
Every time I look at the game, I always want to play it all over again,
but every time i look at the time, well... i don't have enough time, maybe next time, then again and again and again....

because there are some sections that made me not deal with it for at least half a year, sometimes I just tried to find new ways from YouTube, still how and where (at least in the last few sections I was already very stuck more than 1 year ago)

Anyway, I really like it because it's a weird puzzle game where you have to make your own way with triangles, where I want to go and look for the secret ways and of course the exit, the story is not that long, sometimes there are dialogues, especially since I'm one of the foxes who has to find the other fox (I won't spoiler it here)

I've had the game for 2-3 years, it's an old game and maybe not many people have played it, but I still like it (like Single-Player game)

I recommended most for those who have free time and love logic games
(Last time I played it maybe 1 year ago, I just modified it in the game rating)

Non recommandé
0.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 décembre 2015
As appealing as the aesthetic and animation of the game was made by the trailer, I found it literally impossible to play past literally the first level. The nasally, bizarrely-acted voice of the narrator/unsettling masked man was a little bit like getting sandpaper in your ears and certainly began to grate on me after a minute or two, and that was before I got to the actual platforming. The controls are floaty and clunky, at best, and unusable at worst; I felt like I had to slam on the spacebar to get any real movement, and when the second task of the first room required jumping cleanly across, like, eight beams (spaced too close for the sprint jump and too far away for the single jump, forcing you to rely on the touchy "catch/pull up" mechanic) or start the level over, I closed it and resigned to never play it again.
Also: big rooms and motion blur? Not close companions.
 
Un développeur ou une développeuse a répondu à cette évaluation
verboten foyay distributor
1
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 janvier 2015
I've always loved this game's style of art, and so far I've JUST made it to part five. This game needs for you to think outside the box- no, really. If you think inside the box you'll get stuck on 'Unwilling Walls' for at least two hours. Alas, you must also remember the basics and not overthink things, or you'll be doing somethinng horrifically advanced when all you need to do is just on a box and climb up the wall.

Gameplay - 4.5/5
The game spoonfeeds you the details and the things that you, the PC, can do. Theres no massive 'jump' and you're not alone in this journey, so if you find youself getting lost you should look back and try to run through things from the beginning and see if it's possible. Also, try to collect the Idols of Useless Knowledge, you really do need them. The art is amazing.

Style - 5/5
Did I not mention I'm already in love with this game? The art style is both cartoonish and real, along with having cutsceens, smooth animations, and a whole new look on things. Put together Antichamber and Portal you'll get this. Honestly, this game is worth your money if you are the type to sit back and enjoy the little details.

Sound - 5/5
Whoever the hell made this needs a trophy, cause they're amazing. Everything has a sound, but let me just fangirl for a moment. The MUSIC. Oh, the music is simply amazing! Get the soundtrack if you must but the music and background noises with both put you on edge and relax you, at the same time. I have honestly, in my whole life as a gamer and an artist/writer, never heard such beautiful music.

Story - 4/5
You don't just play games to play games. Wait, some people do. Never mind that. All considerably additicing games need a good story, and this one's got it. It may seem a bit confusing at first, but like the gameplay the game spoonfeeds it to you, taking babysteps. Instead of your basic 'Once open a time, a hero(the PC) appeared,' theres a while backstory and cause for the mess that has become the realm of the Mad God. Why is there only two foxes? Why is only one considered a god when both are immortal? When are we finally going to catch Red? When is Blue going to show up? The questions haunt my dreams and demand that I come back and search for the answers, and I do.

Overall - 18.5/20
This game is... well, plainly put it: Amazing. There has been no other games in all 1,000+ hours of steam gameplay that I've done that has wow'ed me in such a way. The game is smoothly put together and everything fits. It a massive milk puzzle, ( If you don't know what a milk puzzle is, it's a normal puzzle expect for that it's all white ) and /you/ have to be the one to paint the pieces in your own understanding a pathway in this game. If you find that the game is impossible, think this: The word 'Impossible' itself says 'I'm possible'! If I could, I'd buy twenty copies of this game and send every one of them to each one of my friends, I simply cannot get enough of TRI.... if only I wasn't stuck on the fifth level. Heh.
 
EnigmaticBird

Bending over cows for milkshake
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
25.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 juillet 2019
This is truly a fantastic game that is criminally overlooked.

A wonderful mind bending spatial based puzzler, where you create triangles on the environment for traversal, and as the game progresses, these tris gain more elaborate abilities.

The art direction and music are just stellar. Bold use of colours, surreal spaces, a somewhat painted feel to the textures and characters and their looks on the visual department. And the music is some of the most unique I've heard on any game. Most of the time I'd start whit "what the hell is this" as a reaction, but a few mins later I'd end up singing along the wordless vocal side of the songs.

The level design is fantastic, having a grid-like style construction of 1mx1m squares for most of the game, to give the player a consistent measure as to better construct the squares, but not limiting rigidly to this for when it's not necessary. New ideas and mechanics are introduced to diff worlds, and often using a few same basic mechanics in drastically different ways, as well as puzzles often having multiple ways to solve.

The maps have tons of strange areas and nooks and crannies, where collectibles are hidden, and these are super fun to find. Not only that, but areas where you'd think you are breaking the map to get to... often have these collectibles inside em, or achievements with lil easter eggs.

By the end of the game I found myself kinda sad cause I was having such a good time, even tho the game has a really good number of puzzles, wishing there were even more to solve.

All in all, I can't recommend this game enough.
 
Dragon Denton:Pretty Cute Trash

Évaluation publiée le 12 octobre 2014
A mind-bending, fox collecting puzzle game you say? An intriguing puzzle game with a nice atmosphere and great art. Long enough that you get value for money. If you like Portal etc, this is worth a look. Full review here:

28.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 octobre 2017
Just finished this game... It was a fun and challenging 3D first person puzzler that is extremely beautiful. Some really different mechanics that make you think, and then rethink some of the concepts you though you always understood about these types of games, like gravity for one.

The game guides you pretty well through the challenges, but doesn't hand them to you, and the puzzles progress in a way that makes sure you understand the next stage mechanic without shoving it down your throat.

Relaxing music that doesn't chip away at your soul after hearing it for 20 hours and it has a good story line and background.

All in all, this is probably one of my favorite first person 3D puzzle platforms of all time, highly recommended.

It's also lengthy enough to find a home on your computer if you want to take it slow and play between other games. Fans of Okami, or Japanese style and folklore will be very happy with this one.

Recommandé
38.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 mars 2015
About 36 hours of total play time, and I finally beat Tri: Of Friendship and Madness. Though the game is heavily derivative of Portal, it quickly goes in its own direction with the puzzles.

And difficulty.

After a tutorial level, you're given a Tri, a device that makes triangles which you can use to bridge gaps and make pathways up the walls and along the ceiling. In later levels you use them to reflect light beams, guide lasers, and more! And then you are told to find the fox.

The first ten levels or so are tantalizing and brain-teasing enough, and then level 11 hits. From 11 to the end, the puzzles are MEAN! Multi-step, thinking outside the box, taking these game mechanics and stretching what you can do with them to the very edge of reason! There are some strange maneuvers you have to pull off, and figuring out what you have to do requires paying close attention to the environment.

The puzzles are mean in a good way. Everything you need to solve them is right in front of you. Learning to recognize what is possible with all these devices, how they behave, and how you must use the triangles to make them work together is mind-stretching. This is not for casual players, and I like that.

These are expertly-designed levels. Nothing is unfair, nothing is obtuse. I finished the game without consulting a walkthrough, or taking any hints, and I am proud to have figured everything out by myself. Those last two levels are a doozy--each taking me two sittings to figure out--but everything is logical.

The story is a bit thin. It's told between levels instead of experienced as you progress, but that's a minor gripe. I can see how the foxes went mad with this kind of freedom of movement. I almost went mad figuring this stuff out. Forget thinking with portals. Thinking with Tris will kick your butt!

I have only one real complaint: the music. It's not bad music, but the way it's used is. Each level has a segment of music which lasts one to two minutes, and this clip plays over and over and over, with about 30 seconds of silence in between. On some levels, I heard the same 1-minute loop a hundred times, and it became so tiresome I often switched off the music and played my own. The soundtrack is so much better when it's not broken up and looped. I bought it as a symbol of my triumph!

Other than this flaw, it's a wonderful game. Superbly crafted levels, excellent use of its game mechanic, and foxes!
 
tagenar
127 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
18.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 décembre 2014
Man this was a hidden gem among the collection of bizarre puzzle games. If you've played Antichamber, Quantum Conundrum, Portal 2, and maybe a little of Stanley Parable for the madness bit....then you're going to love this. From what I gathered of the story (avoiding spoilers here), you are called upon to assist a holy guardian to help his friend, but both have lost their way.

TRI challenges the player to invent their own solution to accomplish a similar goal in varying worlds of what seem to represent insanity. Yup. You're going to lose track of which way is up.... in levels that actually have a defined "up".....and it's so much fun. The tools at your disposal are basically hands (to lift), feet (to move), mind (to go insane), and TRIangles (to defy physics, of course). The TRIangles are your control among the madness, allowing you to define which way is up.

I loved playing this so much, from the very strange but addictive soundtrack to the way it throws you into each scenario without holding your hand.

Évaluation publiée le 4 janvier 2015
This game is similar to Portal in terms of being a 3D puzzle platformer which gives you a basic tool and gradually gives you more information about how to use it as you go along. In terms of tone, it's nothing like Portal. Where Portal is all about some very dark humor in a sci-fi setting, TRI takes you through an absolutely beautiful world of myths and glorious red triangles.

TRI is wonderful. 100% recommend it.

Awesome puzzle game. The main idea is as simple as drawing polygons, but combining their functionality with clever level design you get almost endless amount of varying logical problems to solve. If that is not enough, one can hunt for more or less hidden golden idols - getting all of them is a serious challenge.

The game has a few issues, but I won't even bother to point them out :P
If You love puzzlers, then this is a must have.

Tri plantea un sistema de puzzles basado en la creación de triangulos que alteran la gravedad, es complicado de explicar porque es algo muy visual, así que recomiendo ver un video suyo por internet para comprenderlo mejor... A game about jumping on platforms with mediocre controls and poor jump/climb mechanics. You will fall a lot, so developers implemented quick save-load feature. Every level has a timer (which encourages speedrunning) and a bunch of optional "secret" objectives. The game desperately try to recreate that fancy surreal feeling, but it's still too far away from titles like Antichamber or, say, Qbeh. The music is nice though.

Évaluation publiée le 14 juillet 2021
TRI is sadly full of bad game design. Finding every idol requires combing every square in every level to find movable bricks that otherwise blend seamlessly into the wall. At one point you cannot progress in the story unless you figure out that an entire wall is made of these bricks. While the mechanics are generally alright the stage-design in TRI takes all the fun out of them.

Next to the Portal series, this is my favorite platformer ever.
The mechanics are creative, everything just works, and there's the insane joy of exploring everything.
I will admit, it does get a little repetitive over time, but that's it's only drawback.

This game is extremely casual: still very fun, but it's not at all fast-paced unless you're trying to speedrun.

That being said, the game is still a puzzle game and definitely has challenge to it.

Évaluation publiée le 12 septembre 2018
Tutorial and second chapter were both good. Enjoyment took a nosedive the moment I picked up the "Tri" - a tool that enables you to draw triangles for stepping on in midair, but:
  • The radius of this tool is tiny, doesn't even span the room you're supposed to practise in.
  • Each vertex has to be attached to a surface, effectively disabling air bridges and being painfully unintuitive to draw and navigate with.
Good thing I got this on sale, my hopes weren't high to begin with. Centering your gameplay around some ill-thought-out gimmick? Costs more than the Assassin's Creed Lost Archives sidegame, and is still beaten.

0
Recommandé
24.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 avril 2021
A NEW (TRI)ANGLE
Check out my Curator Page for more hidden gems: REVIEWS
TLDR: Creative and tough puzzle game about making triangles to navigate your way through a colorful geometric realm to rescue a fox.

TRI is a first-person puzzler that manages to juggle a surprisingly rich variety of puzzle elements based on its simple gameplay premise: making triangles. What starts out as a simple game mechanic for walking across pits gradually becomes part of increasingly intricate challenges involving complex geometric puzzles, spatial reasoning, gravity shifting, teleportation, orientation control, particle deflection, and light reflection (A LOT of light reflection). And I mean it when I say that the challenges become increasingly intricate... there are some serious difficulty spikes in the second half of the game, where having to make literally hundreds of triangles per level can quickly become time-consuming and tedious. Nonetheless, finally solving the puzzles is always very rewarding, as the harder solutions usually require you to be creative in a lot of different ways.

TRI is totally worth playing, not only due to the unexpected depth of its triangle manipulation gameplay, but also because of its colorful visuals, creative level design, well-placed secret collectibles, and awesomely quirky soundtrack ("boink bong bink bong"). The game pushes geometric puzzles to their limits, and players should get in shape (triangularly of course) for a fiesta of tough but rewarding challenges.
 
AzureAlpha

Évaluation publiée le 19 mars 2016
Игра мне очень понравилась, всем любителям головоломок советую!
Плюсы:
+Картинка. Очень приятная графика и плавная анимация. FPS не просидают, игра не виснет.
+Сюжет. Сюжет выглядит очень интересным, но пока что не могу сказать точно, так как игра пройдена не полностью.
+Головоломки. Достаточно интересные. На данном этапе игры не очень сложные.
Минусы:
-Звуковое сопровождение. Когда лезишь на возвышенность, звук жутко раздражает.
-Во врему "прогулки" по стенам случаются подвисания.

+- Музыка. Оценивать музыку сложнее всего, так как в целом она хороша, но я не большой поклонник подобного жанра.

Вердикт:
В целом игра очень хороша, но некоторые минусы всеже имеются.
Моя оценка 9,5 идолов из 10



И вот вам ссылочка на мой канал, там вы можете посмотреть прохождение данной игры и других.
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2BNe-JiCX8SV9n_xMeiW3A

Приятная глазу головоломка от первого лица. Первые уровни проходятся легко, но чем дальше, тем сложнее.

Совет: положение углов треугольника можно менять, пока он полупрозначный. Просто возьмите курсором черный шарик в углу и меняйте. Это поможет точнее скорректировать отраженный луч света.

198 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 décembre 2016
Produit reçu gratuitement

Full Disclosure: I stopped playing this game around level 8 out of 15, so about half way through.

If you are looking for a casual and relaxing labyrinth puzzle, TRI is an OK choice. It has a calming soundtrack, the levels are atmospheric, and the controls are simple. It's easy to pick up and dig into. It's a game that you can play without having to think about anything which is part of why I dislike it. TRI has a novel and simple mechanic where the player draws triangles on walls to create new platforms, thereby allowing them to explore a 3D maze and collect objects. The problem is that this mechanic is too simple for its own good. It pairs poorly with the environment and rapidly becomes tedious.

The game scales difficulty not by scaling the use of the triangle mechanic but instead by scaling the size and convolutions of the mazes. The player never has to be clever about drawing a triangle, they simply need to draw more of them. As a comparison: Imagine if in the game Portal, instead of each subsequent test chamber introducing a new puzzle it introduced the exact same puzzle but just forced you to solve it multiple times. Throw on top of that a portal gun with unlimited portals and you will have the game TRI. It's a puzzle-game with no puzzles, or at least with simplistic ones. In many respects it is a 'walking-simulator' masquerading as a puzzle game.

Now, I am a huge fan of 'walking-simulators', so I can readily accept a tedious game mechanic. However, in order for a player to suffer tedium they must be rewarded with something, such as beathtaking visuals, a sense of accomplishment, or an exciting story. TRI does not deliver on any of these. Yes, it's pretty, but not in a captivating way. The architecture is uniformly limited to blocky shapes and a flat color palette. While this makes the game atmospheric, it also makes it visually unrewarding to explore. All the rooms look the same. Yes, there is a story, but it is similarly flat, bookending levels with 15 second segments that are more motif than story. Do you as the player discover hidden pieces of the story as you explore a level? No. Do you discover the purpose of these mazes? No. Can you impact the story? No. You have one job to do, and it is to draw triangles, lots of tedious triangles.

Overall, TRI is a game with only about 15 minutes worth of content stretched out into a 6-hour gameplay.

However, I do expect many people will thoroughly appreciate this game for its visual flavor alone and the triangle mechanic. If you are looking for a casual game don't let my review sway you. Give TRI a try. But if you are looking for a challenge with varied puzzles, a rich story, cerebral mechanics, or simply fantastic visuals, move on by.
 
ruefrost
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
22 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé

They're such a perfect shape. Three points, three sides, they're so friendly but also intimidating and bold at the same time. They're perfection in shape form. Triangles are perfect. And if you love triangles you are perfect too.

5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 décembre 2016
This game isn't for everyone. I don't think it's a bad game, so I'm a bit iffy on not recommending it, but it's a game that doesn't respect my time.

As one progresses through the game, the levels become bigger and more intricate, and the amount of work one has to do becomes exponentially bigger. It's not that the game is insanely hard, it's just insanely tedious. The main mechanic of the game is to create triangles to use as platforms, or to place them on walls to be able to walk up the walls. So that's what you spend most of your time doing. Creating triangles to be able to get from one place to another. This isn't something that requires thought, this is just busywork. I got up to level 7 or 8, and when I saw just how big the map was, I gave up with the game.

And not even bother with the collectibles. Ffs, they are a pain in the arse to get to. I spent half an hour travelling the outside of a level to find one or two collectibles, and I might have had to restart the whole level because I triggered an event in the game by accident, preventing me from leaving a room afterwards. Either I restarted the level, or I spent ten more minutes building triangles until I reached the ceiling and escaped through there; I can't remember.

Other reviews mention later that you have to use triangles to reflect lasers, and that you get to teleport. Frankly, I'm afraid of just how tedious things would get after that.

Don't get me wrong, this isn't a bad game. I think it's a lovely game. It has foxes in it, and I love foxes, so I immediately love the game. The levels are pretty, the idea behind the game is fun, and the story is a nice enough motivation to play the game. Wanting to know what happened with the foxes was my only reason to play. But the game doesn't respect my time, and I have better uses for my time.
 
Fluffy Friends& ΘΔ 🐾 Ⓥ
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0

Non recommandé
1.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 novembre 2017
It was ok at first, and then walking on walls was introduced. Really, don't play this if you get motion sickness.

So far the puzzles are definitely solvable, but the real difficulty is actually executing them. After figuring out what you need to do, the process of performing the solution is probably what takes the longest. It's hard to tell if certain triangles will let you walk up certain places, even with the red and yellow guidances

The art style is nice but gets boring because the design never changes, most likely because the actual narrative doesn't take you anywhere as well. As a comparison, with Portal there's a sharp contrast between the test chambers and the "behind the scenes", with The Talos Principle each "world" has a different design. Only a handful of colors are used in the game as well.

Similarly the music does its job, but also gets tiresome quickly

TL;DR - Motion sickness, tedious puzzles and monotone art/music
 
tendrils

Évaluation publiée le 9 septembre 2015
Rien ne m'a donné envie d'aller au delà du troisième niveau. On progresse sans réel but ou motivation (ramasser des items à la ♥♥♥ ça ne compte pas), on ne croise pour ainsi dire personne (les renards ça ne compte pas), les décors sont vides et sans âmes (mettre des triangles partout ça ne compte pas) et tracer des triangles pour avancer devient vite répétitif.

Je ne suis vraiment pas friand de ces jeux qui se contentent de nous faire traverser des "salles à la Portal" sans jamais prendre la peine de nous impliquer dans un univers (scénario, mise en scène, personnages, surprises...). Coller une feature plus ou moins originale ou bien utilisée ne me suffit pas.

Ce qui me désole un peu car j'ai vraiment adoré la série Portal et quelques rares autres jeux du genre. L'offre a beau être conséquente ces dernières années (la mode, tout ça), on tourne souvent autour des mêmes choses (niveaux inutilement alambiqués, minimalisme, absence de scénario/sens, look "arty", même mécanique surexploitée...). Il y a à coup sûr un public pour ça mais je n'en fait pas parti. Il faut dire que je suis un gros ♥♥♥. Ca joue aussi.

Recommandé
9.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 mars 2016
TRI is a first-person puzzle like The Talos Principle or Portal. This game consists of unique puzzle solving and exploration,mostly for secrets.

The main mechanic of this game is building triangles. Just select three points in a certain area to create a triangle to make your own plattforms to reach new stuff. New mechanics are added to this later like being able to walk on walls or the ceiling with the triagles or light puzzle.
There is a background story which is being told with the cut scenes between the levels or the narrator which leads you through the levels at some points.
My main problems with this game are the jumping at times and how the levels seem to drag on a bit too long if you want to collect the collectables which are very well hidden at times. If you don't care about stuff like that then the pacing of the game might feel better.

All in all, this game makes a good impression and I ended up playing like 3h when I first started it, it also has a unique art stlye to it.

TRI: Of Friendship and Madness

Évaluation publiée le 16 décembre 2018
TRI: Of Friendship and Madness – это игра, где вам нужно будет собрать ТРИ статуи лиса, проходя головоломки, используя ТРИугольники, которые вы создаете благодаря штуке, называемой TRI (всего будет ЧЕТРЫРЕ TRI). Гейб ненавидит эту игру.

Игра интересная и красивая, но иногда бывают ситуации, когда не знаешь что делать (именно "что" делать, а не "как"). Также, здесь есть немного раздражающие отверстия, которые по своей размерности равны размерости кубика (ящика) из-за чего очень трудно протиснуть кубик в это отверстие. Но они в основном попадаются только рядом с идолами, которые собирать не обязательно. Любителям необычных головоломок и сюрреализма рекомендую. Сюжет так же необычен, как и визуальная часть

1.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 octobre 2014
That game is a truly unique experience, which is only possible on a PC (probably a Wii U, too), because it needs good first person controls and benefits from a precise but fast pointing device like a mouse.
The game play is innovative. You may be reminded of other games but using triangles to solve puzzles permits you to do it with a lot of freedom. And the puzzles are challenging and diversified, so the game performs as a flagship of its genre.
Furthermore the beautiful artistic style and soundtrack cover so much individuality that I am able to assign it to the game instantly, when I see or hear a piece of it.

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
10.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 janvier 2018
Never finished the last level.

(Minor spoilers)

This game is very hard; at least the second half or so. Make the quick save key your friend because you'll be reloading from your last save a lot once you get past the first few levels. After awhile you'll be falling off levels or getting killed by laser beams every few minutes or so.

On many occasions I was very close to giving up, but I got all the way to the last puzzle... and was completely stuck. I spent literally 2-3 hours directing the laser beam around to all parts of the level including places you mightn't think possible, I was a master of the triangles... except I wasn't getting anywhere.

Eventually, after a couple of weeks went by it was clear I was never going to go back again, I had done everything there was to do. So I looked up the steam thread and read some solutions until I thought I had an idea how to do it. But then I actually watched a walkthrough and realised that there was no way I ever would have figured that out. Even with the instructions from the Steam thread I don't think I would have been able to do that. I know some people did figure it out, so I guess it sounds silly for me to say, but I actually think it was really unfair. The solution is so specific, with almost no clues in the preceeding gameplay as to what needs to be done. And I had already tried some things that were not part of the game, including directing that laser at objects and into rooms that I doubt the devs ever expected anyone to do.

So it is with a bit of sadness that I have now had to watch the end of of the game on someone else's video. I'm still glad I played and I definitely got my money's worth, but I think the game falls down on the last hurdle. A game should be fun and a reasonably competent gamer should be able to finish the game with the skills developed during the play of that game. To introduce hidden rules in the last puzzle is not fair.

Steam says I have played this game for 10 hours, but it is at least double that. I dont' know how steam tracks gameplay time but it is almost always very wrong for games I have played for any serious amount of time.
 
CascadeHush
719 produits enregistrés

Évaluation publiée le 18 janvier 2017
Au delà de la découverte qui est vraiment sympa, compter 3h, et bien après cela, j'ai arrêté au 3eme niveau...
Pourquoi ?

Une histoire impalpable, qui n'incite pas à s'impliquer dans le jeu. Peut-être un peu trop métaphorique. En tout cas ont a du mal à lier les petites scènes d'animation avec le jeu...

La conception des niveaux et beaucoup trop étriquée, ce qui déclenche une sensation d’oppression.
Alors que j'ai adoré portal 1 et 2. Je ne m'attendais pas à ramper dans des zones de la taille d'un conduit de ventilation !

Dommage de ne pas pouvoir choisir les niveaux.
Je ne pense pas que j'y reviendrais.

Un détail: pourquoi le Vsync limite les FPS à 40 ? obligé de la désactivé et là ils s'envolent à 200/300 ! n'importe quoi, obligé de lancer RivaTuner Statistics Server.

Évaluation publiée le 10 avril 2016
Okay, so ignoring the horribly unoptimized Unity engine running at <30fps running Quake 2 levels of geometry
AAAND ignoring having to modify the camera settings so you don't vomit everywhere...
I couldn't finish this game.
The story made no sense to me and I got sick of doing the same thing over and over again.
I did like the music and the art style.

But how much of "Make a bunch of triangles to get to another room, possibly find a statue" can one take?

If the game were optimized or moved to an engine that ran sanely, if the story gave you a clear sense of purpose, and if there were some new mechanics like moving or teleportation triangles to keep things fresh this could have been a classic.

Recommandé
3.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 mars 2015
I've not gotten close to finishing the game yet, but I can at least put in some first thoughts.

Overall, it seems to be a really good first-person puzzle game. Expect to be confused, though.

I'm not going to go over everything that's good about the game, that would take too long. Instead, I'll go over everything you might not like. Unless these things are enough to turn you off of a game, you should probably get it, if you seem interested.

-The soundtrack is interesting. I really like it, but I'm not entirely sure everyone would.

-I'm not a huge fan of the voice acting. It's passable, though, and there's not too much of it.

-If you easily get motion sickness, be careful, things can get very disorienting sometimes, and it could probably make you sick if you're not okay with that.

Other than these few things, the game is pretty great. And the mechanics are cool.
If you're still not sure whether you want it, just wait for a sale or something.

Évaluation publiée le 30 mars 2015
TRI: Of Friendship and Madness is an interesting platforming game. I like the Japanese feudal setting. The artstyle isn't my favorite, but that's just my opinion. When I bought this I guess I didn't realize that it was first person point of view. This can make the puzzles frustrating (jumping on beams and then falling to the floor only to have a long trek back to where you were). The camera isn't the best, so that also annoyed me when jumping. Overall, I like the game, but the point of view, and maybe combined with the controls made this challenging for me.
 
certifiablygeeky
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
96.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 décembre 2017
ステージクリア型の謎解きアドベンチャーゲームでステージは全16章
各ステージには狐の壇像が3つどこかに配置されていて、それらを探し集めて石壇へ供えることでステージクリアとなるシンプルなゲームだ

このゲームにはタイトルの通り、自由な位置に三角形を描き足場にすることで本来到達できない場所へ移動できるといった特徴がある
この三角形を描いたり消したりしてステージクリアを目指そう

しかしながらステージクリアするだけがこのゲームの目的ではない
各ステージには更に数多くのシークレット像が隠されていて、全16章でその数148個にも上る
つまりこのゲームの肝は全てのシークレットを探し集めることであり、一筋縄ではいかない
シークレットを集めることで制作の舞台裏や開発者のコメントなどボーナスコンテンツがアンロックされる仕組みとなっている

謎解きゲームに飢えているならばぜひオススメしたいタイトルだ
 
pikero

BennLP
320 produits enregistrés

5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
22.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 novembre 2016
The game annoyingly asks to you leave a review every single time you load it up. It's almost as bad as eBayers who email you 30 seconds after the end of the auction begging for positive feedback. So here you go.

TRI is tedious. It has a really good premise, and it's quite pretty to look at, in a polygonal sort of way. The mechanic is an interesting one - the ability to create solid platforms on which you can stand to move yourself around the place. Unfortunately, that seems to be the only mechanic. Whereas in Portal the game introduces new ideas on a regular basis, this game seems to quickly run out of ideas and you spend 80% of your time doing the same thing - producing a series of overlapping triangles so you can move up a wall. Remember how towards the end of Portal 2 you had to climb up the shaft by repeatedly using the slingshot technique? Well, that's most of the game here. Many times I just got bored and closed the game because I was utterly fed up with doing exactly the same thing over and over and over and over again.

It's a shame. This game had a lot of potential, but it suffers from far too much padding. And it's glitchy. The "wall running" code in particular seemed to hate me...I'd be walking along the wall from triangle to triangle, and suddenly the game would decide "Nope. You're not doing that any more", switch the gravity back to normal, and I'd fall all the way down and have to start again. It's inconsistent - most "deaths" in the game such as falling off the end of the map simply teleport you back to solid ground with no penalty. And then half way through the game, it starts introducing elements which CAN kill you, with no warning. Hope you remembered to save!

In addition, the game has a Linux port. Now, normally this is cause for celebration as too few developers make the effort, so it should be applauded. However, it's been done in the second-laziest way possible (The laziest being to stick a WINE wrapper around it and call it a day). There IS a Linux version, but there's no support. I suffered a problem which meant the game wouldn't start, and when I asked for help, the developers replied "Yeah...sorry. We don't actually know anything about Linux so we can't help. You should ask for a refund.". Given we have to pay the same for the game as Windows players, why should we have to provide our own tech support? I'm building up an increasingly large list of games in my inventory which have a Linux port, but they're broken and the developer either can't ("We no longer have access to the code") or won't (they just ignore us) fix it. (Randal's Monday, Bit Dungeon II, Edna & Harvey - The Breakout, 6180 The Moon etc)) If you're lucky, they remove the Linux version from the store to stop other people making the same mistake, but that's no consolation to those of us who bought it first.

As it happens, the game started working again...but I know that if I have the same problem, I'm on my own. It's dishonest and misleading to proudly claim to support Linux, but then just shrug when there are any issues. If you can't support and assist people then it shouldn't have been released,

However, I don't think I'll be finishing it as the game is too boring. Sorry. I might come back to it in the future, but for now it's on the "Can't be bothered to finish" pile.
 
Hamakei
4,079 produits enregistrés
1
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Évaluation publiée le 24 décembre 2016
Produit reçu gratuitement

This game is simply amazing so far.

I did have to change the frames per second down to 30 to keep from frying my video card (I have -no- idea what's causing it to run so dang hot when I play this, but it runs much cooler at just 30 frames per second).

However... after that worry was out of the way, I've been methodically working through the levels to find the golden useless idols throughout the game. Just that and exploring the levels top to bottom is amazing. It really is my kind of game when I think I've somehow made it up somewhere unintended, just to see there's a golden idol waiting for me. The feeling is indescribeable. :D

Évaluation publiée le 25 avril 2017
I actually bought a new computer while I was playing this and just never got around to finishing it (its on the old hard drive) however I really liked what I had played I probably was about 3/4 the way through the game and the atmosphere and game mechanics were great I'll update this review when I get around to it again and beat it (the powers you get make you feel powerful)

Edit: I decided to go and replay the game so that I can say I played the entire thing however even though I had reformatted my laptop which i had initially played this game on (the save was deleted essentially) I was able to jump right back into my old save when I had downloaded the game onto my computer which saved me a good amount of time.

I had to use a walkthough 2 times once because I had gotten into an area with wittyness and I couldn't beat it because I was supposed to have entered through a way that changed gravity first but because I hadn't the entire puzzle room was on its side on level 15 and then the very last puzzle I had no clue what the game wanted me to do

other than that this game feels very open in the possibilities to complete levels
another thing is this game ran like a dream even after 350+ triangles put down I still had 180-200+ fps with an rx 480 4gb

this game wont be for everyone but for puzzle enthusiasts this is a fun one
 
Mineswee

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Non recommandé
1.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 octobre 2014
TRI has a beautiful art style and interesting gameplay concepts, but unfortunately, an hour in it became unplayable for me. The mechanic of walking up walls gave me motion sickness so I had to stop playing (I've never had motion sickness playing a game before, and am generally fine on rollercoasters etc, so it came as a surprise). There was no indication in the trailer of the camera behaving in this way. Unfortunately, as a result, I can't recommend this game.

In addition, the voice acting and script was awful - the guide character was very poorly cast for such a central role to the game. Perhaps due to budget restraints, he was voiced by a member of the dev team? The music varied widely from hard to listen to to beautiful. It's a shame, as the art direction and concept had excellent treatment - the sound design really should have had the same care taken.
 
Risachantag
2

Recommandé
14.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 octobre 2014
Atmospheric and intuitive, this game brings a lot to the table with well designed puzzles, an amazing soundtrack and charming story. The game starts of pretty fun, but starts to become awe inspiring as you get further in the game and are challenged further. It is very surprising how well the TRI can be controlled, the anti-gravity mechanics are some of the best I've seen in a game. Easily my top 3D puzzle game since Portal, if you are looking for something to fill the void, look no further. Highly recommended!

Check out my video for more of my first impressions:
Vidéo YouTube™: TRI: Of Friendship and Madness | Quickplay (First Impressions / Review) 
Vues : 4,836
This gameplay is of my Quickplay (review / first impressions) for the indie portal-esque puzzle game TRI: Of Friendship and Madness by Rat King Entertainment.
 
Retromation
2,001 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 décembre 2016
FPSパズルアクションゲーム。

基本的には三角形の足場を作って登ったり壁を歩いたりして進むパズルゲームです。
ステージ内にある3つの像を集めたらクリア。あとシークレットの像も集める。

最初の方は面白かったけど、中盤から完全にゴリ押し総当りゲー。
まずシークレットの数が多すぎ。大量に置いてあるもんだから一部は全然隠されてない。
隠されていたとしてもステージの外とか壁とかを全部調べて見つける感じ。
全然見つけたときの喜びがない。
ステージに３つくらいはしっかり隠されてるのがあるので、それだけでよかったのに。

ギミックも凝ってるけど、微妙にわかりづらい。
というかステージが広すぎてめっちゃ迷う。
その割に繋がってたりするからもう大変。
そしてこのゲームはゴリ押しでどこにでもいけるのでもうめちゃくちゃ。
ステージをクリアするのに1時間以上かかります。
多分作者もよくわかってないようで、一回普通に箱を置いてきたら取れなくなってしまいました。
当然ステージの最初からやり直しです。

大体、最初の方は何しても死なないし、奈落の底に落ちても普通にその場復活してたのに
途中から出てくる酸で即死GAMEOVERってのが頭おかしすぎる。
何しても死なないって知ってるからセーブなんて当然してないわけで、またステージの最初からやらされました。
そしてステージはゴリ押し・・・。

ゲームの雰囲気は良いです。
随所に挟まるキツネの物語と、変なBGM。
雰囲気ゲーとしてみれば良いゲームだと思います。
 
yuuutu

Un développeur ou une développeuse a répondu à cette évaluation
DALOS
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
8.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 décembre 2016
I like the idea of this game (Tag: The Power of Paint in its concept), but there are a few things that make it not very good. Keep in mind this is a Unity Engine game. I have trouble with these kind of games because I feel my machine isn't powerful enough to run it smoothly.

Pros:
  • Relaxing feel to it.
  • Concept is interesting.
  • Game isn't the worst Unity Engine game I have played. I got a decent 20-30FPS toning down all the graphical settings.

♥♥♥♥:
  • Accidental deletion of triangles. Holding the button for a second or two would improve this situation.
  • Controls feel floaty and sluggish. I've had better control in Source and Unreal Engine games, such as Portal 2 and Antichamber. I have accidently fallen many times. I've even fallen at weird angles jumping off the triangles when I wanted to!
  • Hard to judge how to position the the triangles when climbing walls.
  • Getting lost or stuck easily (progression of the level, not glitches).
  • Wall and ceiling running messes with my sense of down. Tag had an indicator which way was down.
  • The difficulty gets too hard too fast. I probably don't feel comfortable with the controls.
  • Tediousness with completing the level and using the main mechanic. I thought this game would be a puzzle game rather than a collect-a-thon. A puzzle would entail limiting the number of triangles one can produce and being careful how you traverse the level.

With these issues as they currently stand, I'm going to have to not recommend it. If the developers made the mechanic less tedious like Tag is, maybe the game would play better. To me, this game is a game that looks nice but has generic gameplay being aided by wall and ceiling walking. I really wish I could get a refund for this game after surpassing Valve's 2-hour limit. I didn't even beat TRI.
 
wildgoosespeeder

What You Need to Know:

C

Paid: $4

calibrojosh10
570 produits enregistrés
1
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
51.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 octobre 2014
This one almost fell through the cracks. Glad I found it . Now on chapter 8 and I do not know how many chapters are left. Challenging enough with very cool graphics and atmosphere. The music is nice and soothing but gets a bit repetetive through each chapter. The mechanics of TRI building can sometimes be frustrating but I guess that add's to the challenge of puzzle solving. Great save system truly minimizes frustration that many new adventure games ignore. If you like puzzles that make you think then I highly recommend. There is some hand holding but it it is vague, requiring you to think. There are also a few red herrings here and there. No monsters to kill, no unrealistic tasks, no die and start from the beginning.....just thought requirements. The Devs did a nice game here and I rate highly.

Non recommandé
3.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 janvier 2021
This is a fun puzzle/platformer game, but the key problem is that the puzzles are far more finnicky than they should otherwise be.

With full 4K support and decent enough graphics, this passes on the technical implementation. What's left is whether I would recommend such a finnicky and frustrating puzzle game to other games for the rather steep price of $15 USD (which gets you a lot of other, better games). There's no "maybe" options, so sadly this one gets a thumbs down. If only they spent more time polishing and testing the gamers experience.

Évaluation publiée le 22 octobre 2023
It starts really interesting, the artstyle is great and the music is quite fitting. But the puzzles are dragging on and on and the controls are kinda wonly, especially if you are top down on the ceiling and need to draw another triangle to get on a platform, and then suddenly you loose your feet and fall off. I think it would be enjoyable if it wasnt that long, i gave up after 4 hours, because it was just... not interesting enough.

bobrobertson
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
3.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 juillet 2023
К сожалению, изначально игра кажется лучше чем она является на самом деле. Визуальный стиль хоть и прикольный, но каких то интересных решений и красивых пейзажей я в игре не увидел. Головоломки довольно примитивные и не заставляют напрягать мозг, возможно чтобы достать все дополнительные идолы и нужно будет подумать, вот только не известно где они находятся и не известно в какой момент и в какую сторону думать. Но возможно во второй половине игры всё это изменится, но только очень не хочется терпеть кривоватое управление при прыжках и подтягивании за уступы, при изменении гравитации во время использования платформ. Возможно если вам очень понравился визуальный стиль, вы не очень хотите решать сложные пазлы и вы не против часов 10 рутинно рисовать треугольники, то возможно вам стоит обратить внимание на эту игру, для остальных она окажется сильно недокручена.

Odin~@t

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 janvier 2023
No time for a review so I give this game a rank C.
Okay game - not bad but you can skip it or try on sale.
See my profile for more details about my reviews.
Additional notes: So I wonder if I would have enjoyed that game earlier, when it came out, 9 years ago. As of now, sadly, the game is very repetitive, the gameplay is quite heavy and less smooth than needed, and also the story/lore, while full of intriguing potential, falls flat and boring. BUT! The concept and main mechanisms are very unique and well thought. Reach at least level 2 to understand the core idea. Level design is not too bad, although bland and forgettable. If you like puzzle games based on parkour like Portal, you may enjoy this one. Plus, the art is really pretty and colorful.
But finally, I would like to mention something essential: this game has to be commended for giving the green light to an AMAZING SOUNDTRACK. Holy cow, it had been AGES I had not heard such a unique, indie, boundbreaking soundtrack in a game! It reminds me of weird bands like Bran Van 3000 or games like GTA 1/London or JGR/JSRF, and as a musician myself I was baffled by how daring this soundtrack. Very reminiscent of the 90s while mixing traditional music, electro, great! I might never continue this game, but I will listen to the soundtrack!
 
Hem
2,053 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 novembre 2022
Este é daqueles jogos que esteve na lista de desejos durante anos, e agora que finalmente o estou a jogar, e ainda só no capítulo 6, é já um dos meus jogos preferidos.
A estética oriental e o design inteligente, com liberdade para explorar sem restrições, transformam TRI num jogo de puzzles na primeira pessoa bastante belo. As raposas e o ambiente surreal vívido são fantásticos.
O objetivo é simples, desenhar triângulos para aceder às várias áreas, com a possibilidade de caminhar na vertical, até encontrar três estátuas de raposas que depois devem ser colocadas em pedestais para abrir um portal. Existem também pequenas estatuetas colecionáveis, e que convidam a não deixar nada por explorar.
Ao jogá-lo, lembro-me do nível Life of the Party do Thief II. São incontáveis as horas que passei a explorá-lo, e até tentar ir onde não existe nada. Aqui isso acontece, é espetacular vaguear pelos níveis.
A banda sonora é excelente, mas TRI é perfeito para jogar ao som do álbum The Magic Dragon, de Caia.

Recommandé
29.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 mars 2022
I've put over 35 hours into this game. Do I recommend it? Yes. But with some reservations.

I think "Madness" in the title is what it has done to me. Hunting for the most oblique solutions to puzzles, using game mechanics which are rarely advertised. That's IF you can find the puzzles.

The game seems quite deliberately designed to be this hard. Compare that with The Witness with equally challenging puzzles but without the need for pixel-perfect line drawing and precision jumping.

Did I enjoy it? I'm not sure. I've finished it and the ending is.... nice. But so many times I got close to chucking it in the virtual bin.
 
ChorltonDragon
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
5.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 novembre 2021
Frustratingly tedious and downright stressful. When I solve a puzzle, I feel relieved that it's over rather than satisfied that I was able to complete it. Most puzzles rely on memorizing rooms and searching the level to find a small hole in the wall that you didn't notice on your first five passes.

This is also the first game that has let me experience motion sickness. Some levels were downright nauseating to the point at which I had to look up a tutorial to finish the level as soon as possible.

Were this 7-year-old game cheaper, I would be more understanding. As it stands, I would pay $15 again to get my 5 anxiety-filled hours back. The game has a completion rate of less than six percent and I can see why.

1.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 juin 2021
TRI: Of Friendship and Madness

Odd name eh?

Yeah well its an interesting concept for a puzzle platformer for sure, feels kinda like portal where you need to navigate certain levels using your special TRI maker thingy.. yes you make triangles to create platforms and ramps.

Unique enough, I may come back to this game down the road, fun for the 3 or 4 levels I complete.

7/10 if your into triangles and puzzle platformers

Recommandé
51.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 mai 2021
It's my very first review, because there's no limits to how much I love this game. A puzzle game that gives you the feeling that you can fiddle with it and be extremely creative, solve things from five different angles, while still being very challenging (borderline hardcore, in its last third). It's extremely original and clever, the music is fantastic and the atmosphere very distinctive. If you like Antichamber, Portal, The Witness, you need to try this.

And just in case the dev are actually reading this: thank you so much guys, this is wonderful, I'll keep an eye on what you do and if you feel like making more puzzle games, we'll be thrilled, because you clearly have a knack for it.

Non recommandé
7.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 mai 2021
I feel like I gave this game a fair shake, but in the end I'm just not enjoying it all that much.

The main puzzle mechanic is interesting, being able to draw your own platforms and all, but as I was playing through I just found myself being more frustrated after completing a level than satisfied. You end up drawing a lot of triangles and having to play with some weird mechanics, the most frustrating of which is using the tri's to reflect light beams and if it didn't require such precision, or if there was some sort of additional environmental hint to help out with that, you just keep redrawing the same thing over and over until you accidentally get it right.

You may very well enjoy this game, but for me personally it just felt like an exercise in tedium.
Music is nice though
 
superflydanfry
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
25.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 mai 2021
This is an incredibly fun and unique puzzle game. After playing the first couple of levels I thought it would be quick and easy - don't be fooled. It's no Fish Fillets 2 *shudders*, but the puzzles become rather difficult after you reach the half way point. However, the game continuously adds new and interesting mechanics throughout the game. I was very impressed by the creativity of the puzzles and the designs of the later levels. The music is simply fantastic as well, although it will randomly stops playing on occasion.

There were a couple of puzzles that I couldn't solve and had to look at a guide. I am not the best at puzzle games, but it was frustrating at times. The triangles can also be finicky at times and randomly throw you off the side of the wall. It's not the end of the world since you can quick save, but can be irritating nonetheless.

There are some bonus objects to collect which often just require randomly exploring around the entire level. Many of these are hinted at, but not all. I think there is one or maybe two on each level that require a difficult puzzle to solve, these are generally really challenging and fun despite being optional.

Overall I highly recommend this game. The puzzles walk the line between challenging and fun very well, the music is good, and you'll get quite a few hours out of it. Probably took me about 20 hours while taking my time and going for a lot of the bonus content but not 100%ing it.

Évaluation publiée le 4 septembre 2020
Beautiful art style and soundtrack, the puzzle design is mostly good. But oh boy, the mechanics are so damn janky, navigating the levels can be extremely tedious at times. Finding the collectibles is pretty neat in itself, but then again these gameplay mechanics....
Also, there's no official gamepad support. I mean, the game kinda works with a controller, but not the menus.
Will still finish it probably. And then never touch it again. But the music definitely will stay in my playlist. Best part of the game.

Summary:
Oy, janky hack, mate!
